This method can be used to manage the {@link Query() query} data {@link kAPI_DATA_OPTIONS options}, with it you can add, retrieve and delete elements of the options list, to operate on the whole list you should use its {@link kAPI_DATA_OPTIONS offset}.

The method accepts the following parameters:

  • $theOption: This parameter represents the option, it can take the following values:
    • {@link kAPI_OPT_SAFE kAPI_OPT_SAFE}: Can be a boolean or integer, defaults to FALSE. If FALSE, a database query will not wait for a response. If TRUE, the program will wait for the database response and throw an exception if the operation did not succeed.
    • {@link kAPI_OPT_FSYNC kAPI_OPT_FSYNC}: Boolean, defaults to FALSE. Forces the update to be synced to disk before returning success. If TRUE, a {@link kAPI_OPT_SAFE safe} update is implied and will override setting safe to FALSE.
    • {@link kAPI_OPT_TIMEOUT kAPI_OPT_TIMEOUT}: Integer, if "safe" is set, this sets how long (in milliseconds) for the client to wait for a database response. If the database does not respond within the timeout period, an exception will be thrown.
    • {@link kAPI_OPT_SINGLE kAPI_OPT_SINGLE}: Boolean, used in the {@link kAPI_OP_DEL delete} or {@link kAPI_OP_UPDATE update} operatiosn: if TRUE, only the first object will be affected; if not, all matching objects will be considered.
  • $theValue: This parameter represents either the option value, or the operation to perform:
    • NULL: This value indicates that we want to retrieve the value of the option provided in the previous parameter.
    • FALSE: This value indicates that we want to delete the option provided in the previous parameter.
    • other: Any other value is interpreted as the value of the option selected by the first parameter. Note that, in general, missing options are equivalent to setting the option to FALSE, when the value is a boolean, so turning off an option is the same as removing it.
  • $getOld: Determines what the method will return:
    • TRUE: Return the element or list before it was eventually modified.
    • FALSE: Return the element or list after it was eventually modified.
This tag will hold the default container name.
This include file contains the parent class definitions.
This include file contains the parent class definitions.

An entity can be an individual, and organisation or a legal entity that exists as a unit, rather than being embedded in another object.

In this class we add to the {@link CCodedUnitObject parent} the following properties:

  • {@link kTAG_NAME kTAG_NAME}: This offset represents the entity name, the class features a member accessor {@link Name() method} to manage this property.
  • {@link kOFFSET_EMAIL kOFFSET_EMAIL}: This offset represents the entity e-mail address, it is a scalar property and the class features a member accessor {@link Email() method} to manage it.

The class also features a static {@link DefaultContainer() method} that returns the default container name for objects of this type.

Objects derived from this class will have their {@link _IsEncoded() encoded} {@link kFLAG_STATE_ENCODED flag} set by default and must implement a protected {@link _TokeniseIdentifier() method} that must add tokens to the object {@link _index() index} in order to ensure a unique identifier.

The term global {@link kTAG_GID identifier} represents the un-hashed version of the term local {@link kTAG_LID identifier}.

This value is set automatically by a protected {@link _PrepareCommit() method}, so this method is read-only.

This method can be used to handle the entity {@link kTAG_NAME name}, it uses the standard accessor {@link CAttribute::ManageOffset() method} to manage the {@link kTAG_NAME offset}.

This value should be a string that can be used as a label or as a short definition of the entity. The name may be language dependent, so the type of data stored in this offset is the responsibility of concrete classes.

For a more in-depth reference of this method, please consult the {@link CAttribute::ManageOffset() CAttribute::ManageOffset} method, in which the second parameter will be the constant {@link kTAG_NAME kTAG_NAME}.

This method can be used to manage the entity {@link kOFFSET_EMAIL e-mail}, it uses the standard accessor {@link CAttribute::ManageOffset() method} to manage the {@link kOFFSET_EMAIL offset}:

  • $theValue: The value or operation:
    • NULL: Return the current value.
    • FALSE: Delete the value.
    • other: Set value.
  • $getOld: Determines what the method will return:
    • TRUE: Return the value before it was eventually modified.
    • FALSE: Return the value after it was eventually modified.
This method can be used to retrieve the default container name.
We overload this method to enforce the {@link kFLAG_STATE_ENCODED encoded} modifier.
We overload this method to enforce the {@link kFLAG_STATE_ENCODED encoded} modifier, and we set automatically the global {@link kTAG_GID identifier}.
This include file contains all error code definitions.
This include file contains all message severity definitions.

This class extends the built-in Exception class by adding a series of additional members and functionality.

{@link Severity() Severity} represents the severity of the exception such as error, warning, etc. You are free to set any value, but in this library we support the following standard:

  • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_IDLE Idle}: Idle state.
  • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_NOTICE Notice}: Statistical information or message.
  • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_MESSAGE Message}: A message.
  • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_WARNING Warning}: A warning.
  • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_ERROR Error}: An error.
  • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_FATAL Fatal}: A fatal error.
  • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_BUG Bug}: A bug.

{@link References() References} represent a list of reference values structured as an array of key/value pairs where the key represents the reference label or name and the value the reference value. Labels must be strings, values can be of any type.

Note that this class does not throw exceptions (hahaha), operations that fail are simply aborted.
This data member holds the exception severity.
This data member holds the list of exception references.

The first two parameters follow the inherited interface, the constructor adds support for the extended class members:

  • $theMessage: This parameter represents the inherited message.
  • $theCode: This parameter represents the inherited code.
  • $theSeverity: This parameter holds {@link Severity() the} exception type, level or severity:
    • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_IDLE kMESSAGE_TYPE_IDLE}: This indicates an idle state.
    • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_NOTICE kMESSAGE_TYPE_NOTICE}: This indicates an informative note or message.
    • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_WARNING kMESSAGE_TYPE_WARNING}: This indicates a warning.
    • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_ERROR kMESSAGE_TYPE_ERROR}: This indicates an error.
    • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_FATAL kMESSAGE_TYPE_FATAL}: This indicates a fatal error, in general this should halt program execution.
    • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_BUG kMESSAGE_TYPE_BUG}: This indicates a bug, such exceptions should be logged and forwarded to developers.
  • $theReferences: This parameter holds the exception's references {@link References() list}, it is an array indexed by reference label or term holding the reference value as value.
  • $thePrevious: This parameter represents the previous exception when forwarding.
In this class we return the stack trace.

docblock.description: Set or return the exception severity.
docblock.long-description:
When providing $theValue:

  • NULL: Retrieve the current value.
  • FALSE: Reset the value to NULL.
  • Integer: Set the member to the provided value:
    • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_IDLE kMESSAGE_TYPE_IDLE}: Idle state.
    • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_NOTICE kMESSAGE_TYPE_NOTICE}: A notice is an informative message that does not imply an error, nor a situation that should be handled; it can be considered as statistical data.
    • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_MESSAGE kMESSAGE_TYPE_MESSAGE}: A message is an informative message that is addressed to somebody, although it does not imply an error or warning, it was issued to a receiving party.
    • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_WARNING kMESSAGE_TYPE_WARNING}: Warnings are informative data that indicate a potential problem, although they do not imply an error, they indicate a potential problem or an issue that should be addressed at least at a later stage.
    • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_ERROR kMESSAGE_TYPE_ERROR}: Errors indicate that something prevented an operation from being performed, this does not necessarily mean that the whole process is halted, but that the results of an operation will not be as expected.
    • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_FATAL kMESSAGE_TYPE_FATAL}: Fatal errors are {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_ERROR errors} that result in stopping the whole process: in this case the error will prevent other operations from being performed and the whole process should be halted.
    • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_BUG kMESSAGE_TYPE_BUG}: Bugs, as opposed to {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_ERROR errors}, result from internal causes independant from external factors. A bug indicates that an operation will never execute as stated, it does not necessarily mean that it is {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_FATAL fatal}, but rather that the behaviour of an operation does not correspond to its declaration.

The above mentioned codes are integer based, each state is represented by an interval, we encourage using the above mentioned codes, but this is not enforced.

When setting or resetting the value, the method will return it after any modification was made.

docblock.description: Set or return an exception reference.
docblock.long-description:
This method can be used to set, retrieve and remove exception references. References are a key/value pair that provide additional information on the exception.

  • $theIndex: This represents the reference label or name, if you provide the parameter, it will be used as an array index to either retrieve, set or remove elements, depending on the next parameter's value. If you omit the parameter or pass NULL the method will consider the whole list of references.
  • $theValue: This represents the reference value:
    • NULL: This value indicates that we want to retrieve a reference. If $theIndex is provided, the method will return the entry matching it, if there is no match, the method will return NULL. If $theIndex is omitted or NULL, the method will return the full references array.
    • FALSE: This value indicates that we want to delete a reference. If $theIndex is provided, the method will delete the entry matching it and return NULL. If $theIndex is omitted or NULL, the method will delete all references and return an empty array.
    • Any other type: Other types of value are considered as a value to replace or be added to the references list: if $theIndex is provided, the method will add or replace the matching element in the list and return the eventual value after it was modified. If $theIndex is omitted or NULL, the operation depends on the type of value:
      • array: The provided array will replace the current list and the method will return the list after it was replaced.
      • Any other type: The provided value will be appended to the list by using a numeric index and the method will always return the provided value.

tag.name: param
tag.description: NULL, FALSE, reference value or list.

docblock.long-description: This method can be used to display exceptions in a web browser page.

This method can be used to return the exception trace in the order in which it was called. The main utility of this method is to manage forwarded exceptions.

The method will return an array indexed by file path and line number hash in which the value is either an exception or a trace array. If you run in PHP version < 3.0.x the first element will be an exception and the others will be traces, if you run a higher version of PHP you can forward exceptions, so the elements will be mixed.
This method can be used to return the string representation of a trace argument.

docblock.description: Return the exception trace element as HTML.
docblock.long-description:
This method can be used to return the trace element as HTML code.

The method accepts the following parameters:

  • $theTable: The HTML table in which we want to place the trace.
  • $theElement: The trace element, it must be an array, if any other type is passed, the method will return NULL.

This method can be used to return the provided exception as HTML code, it is assumed that the element will be placed in an HTML table, so the method will return a series of table rows.

The method accepts the following parameters:

  • $theTable: The HTML table in which we want to place the trace.
  • $theElement: The exception, it must be an Exception, if any other type is passed, the method will return NULL.
  • $theSource: This parameter is used to provide a link to the source file:
    • NULL: No source file management.
    • TRUE: The default source file viewer will be used.
    • string: The method will execute the provided string as a shell command line.
This value defines the institute entity type.

This value defines the institute ECPGR acronym.

Cardinality: single.

This value defines the FAO/WIEWS institute types set.

Cardinality: list.

This value defines the FAO/WIEWS institute latitude, it is defined here since it is not provided in standard format.

Cardinality: single.

This value defines the FAO/WIEWS institute longitude, it is defined here since it is not provided in standard format.

Cardinality: single.

This value defines the FAO/WIEWS institute altitude, it is defined here since it is not provided in standard format.

Cardinality: single.
This enumeration indicates that the institute manages plant genetic resources.
This enumeration indicates that the institute manages a germplasm collection.
This enumeration indicates the URL used to download the FAO/WIEWS database export file.
This include file contains the parent class definitions.
This include file contains the local class definitions.

This class overloads its {@link CInstitute ancestor} to implement an institute entity taken from the FAO WIEWS institutes database.

This kind of institutes adds the following properties:

  • {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_EPACRONYM kENTITY_INST_FAO_EPACRONYM}: This offset represents the institute ECPGR {@link EAcronym() acronym}.
  • {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_TYPE kENTITY_INST_FAO_TYPE}: This offset represents the institute set of {@link FAOType() FAO} institute types.
  • {@link kOFFSET_URL kOFFSET_URL}: This offset represents the institute {@link URL() URL}.
  • {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_LAT kOFFSET_kENTITY_INST_FAO_LATLATITUDE}: This offset represents the institute {@link Latitude() latitude}, note this is an integer value.
  • {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_LON kENTITY_INST_FAO_LON}: This offset represents the institute {@link Longitude() longitude}, note this is an integer value.
  • {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_ALT kENTITY_INST_FAO_ALT}: This offset represents the institute {@link Altitude() altitude}, note this is an integer value.

Unlike its {@link CInstitute parent}, this class will use the institute {@link Code() code} as-is for the object unique {@link _id() identifier}, the index {@link HashIndex() hashing} method will not transform the {@link _index() index} since it is at most 7 characters thus cannot conflict with other {@link CEntity entity} identifiers.

This method can be used to handle the institute ECPGR {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_EPACRONYM acronym}, it uses the standard accessor {@link CAttribute::ManageOffset() method} to manage the {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_EPACRONYM offset}.

This value should be a string.

For a more in-depth reference of this method, please consult the {@link CAttribute::ManageOffset() CAttribute::ManageOffset} method, in which the second parameter will be the constant {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_EPACRONYM kENTITY_INST_FAO_EPACRONYM}.

This method can be used to handle the institute FAO/WIEWS {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_TYPE types} list, it uses the standard accessor {@link CAttribute::ManageArrayOffset() method} to manage the list of acronyms.

Each element of this list should indicate an acronym by which one refers to the current institute, the nature and specifics of these elements is the responsibility of concrete classes.

For a more thorough reference of how this method works, please consult the {@link CAttribute::ManageArrayOffset() CAttribute::ManageArrayOffset} method, in which the second parameter will be the constant {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_TYPE kENTITY_INST_FAO_TYPE}.

This method can be used to handle the institute {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_LAT latitude}, it uses the standard accessor {@link CAttribute::ManageOffset() method} to manage the {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_LAT offset}.

This value is provided as an integer, specialised classes may convert it.

For a more in-depth reference of this method, please consult the {@link CAttribute::ManageOffset() CAttribute::ManageOffset} method, in which the second parameter will be the constant {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_LAT kENTITY_INST_FAO_LAT}.

This method can be used to handle the institute {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_LON longitude}, it uses the standard accessor {@link CAttribute::ManageOffset() method} to manage the {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_LON offset}.

This value is provided as an integer, specialised classes may convert it.

For a more in-depth reference of this method, please consult the {@link CAttribute::ManageOffset() CAttribute::ManageOffset} method, in which the second parameter will be the constant {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_LON kENTITY_INST_FAO_LON}.

This method can be used to handle the institute {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_ALT altitude}, it uses the standard accessor {@link CAttribute::ManageOffset() method} to manage the {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_ALT offset}.

This value is provided as an integer, specialised classes may convert it.

For a more in-depth reference of this method, please consult the {@link CAttribute::ManageOffset() CAttribute::ManageOffset} method, in which the second parameter will be the constant {@link kENTITY_INST_FAO_ALT kENTITY_INST_FAO_ALT}.

docblock.description: Set a value for a given offset.
docblock.long-description: We overload this method to override the {@link _IsInited() inited} {@link kFLAG_STATE_INITED status} of the {@link CInstitute parent} class: FAO institutes may not have a {@link Name() name} set, so we call the {@link CEntity entity} version of this method.

docblock.description: Reset a value for a given offset.

This method can be used to import the institutes list from the current FAO/WIEWS export file, the method expects two parameters:

  • $theContainer: The {@link CContainer container} in which the institutes are stored.
  • $theURL: The download URL of the FAO/WIEWS export file.

The method will return the number of records added and replaced.

Note that the method will commit the records using the {@link kFLAG_PERSIST_REPLACE kFLAG_PERSIST_REPLACE} and {@link kFLAG_STATE_ENCODED kFLAG_STATE_ENCODED} flags.
In this class we do not nodify the provided value, it is supposed to be the FAO institute INSTCODE field.

This class implements a graph edge.

This class extends its {@link CGraphNode parent} class in that its {@link Node() node} property is a relationship node rather than a plain node.
In this class we return the graph {@link Type() type}.

This property corresponds to the node type, or predicate reference, this property is a string, and it is managed directly by the relationship node: we simply wrap this method around the native management:

  • $theValue: The value or operation:
    • NULL: Return the current value.
    • other: Set the value converted to string.
  • $getOld: Determines what the method will return:
    • TRUE: Return the value before it was eventually modified.
    • FALSE: Return the value after it was eventually modified.
We override the {@link CGraphNode parent} {@link CGRaphNode::Node() method} to enforce Everyman\Neo4j\Relationship objects rather than Everyman\Neo4j\Node objects.

This method will wrap the member accessor around the native relationship node, note that the method will not allow to delete a value, you must replace it.

  • $theValue: The value or operation:
    • NULL: Return the current value.
    • Everyman\Neo4j\Node: Set value.
    • other: Raise exception.
  • $getOld: Determines what the method will return:
    • TRUE: Return the value before it was eventually modified.
    • FALSE: Return the value after it was eventually modified.

  • $theValue: The value or operation:

    • other: Raise exception.
  • $getOld: Determines what the method will return:
    • TRUE: Return the value before it was eventually modified.
    • FALSE: Return the value after it was eventually modified.

This class implements a graph node.

The class is derived from {@link CPersistentObject CPersistentObject}, of which it inherits the persistence framework, but it differs profoundly in that, although the class is an ArrayObject, the actual array that it manages is the properties array of the node. In other words, when you add, retrieve and delete properties, you are not doing so with the internal array, but with the node's properties array.

The class features a single data member, the {@link Node() node} which contains a Neo4j node reference.

Since the object requires a valid {@link Node() node} to exist at all times, this may either be an empty one, if we wish to create a new node, or a {@link _Load() loaded} one, this means that it is not possible to use the inherited interface of instantiating the object with array contents, the container provided to the {@link __construct() constructor} must be a Neo4j client.

Note that the class will not cast to an array correctly, you must use the {@link getArrayCopy() getArrayCopy} method to get an array, if you know how to solve this, please do it!
This data member holds the Neo4j node.
In this class we return the graph {@link Node() node} ID.

This method can be used to manage the native node reference, it uses the standard accessor {@link CObject::ManageMember() method} to manage the property:

  • $theValue: The value or operation:
    • NULL: Return the current value.
    • FALSE: Delete the value.
    • Everyman\Neo4j\PropertyContainer: Set value.
    • other: Raise exception.
  • $getOld: Determines what the method will return:
    • TRUE: Return the value before it was eventually modified.
    • FALSE: Return the value after it was eventually modified.

The method will also set the {@link _IsDirty() dirty} {@link kFLAG_STATE_DIRTY status} and the {@link _IsInited() inited} {@link kFLAG_STATE_INITED status} if the node is provided.

This method can be used to relate the current node to anther node, it will return a Everyman\Neo4j\Relationship instance.

The parameters to this method are:

  • $theContainer: The graph container.
  • $thePredicate: The predicate string or edge type.
  • $theObject: The destination node or relationship object node.

The method will return a Everyman\Neo4j\Relationship object, or raise an exception if the operation was not successful.

This method follows the logic of the relateTo() method of Everyman\Neo4j\Node.
This method will return TRUE if the node has an ID, which is assuming it was committed; or FALSE if not.

This class overloads its {@link CContact ancestor} to implement an institute contact entity.

Institutes feature specific properties that are added to the inherited ones:

  • {@link kOFFSET_ACRONYM kOFFSET_ACRONYM}: This offset represents the institute list of {@link Acronym() acronyms}.
  • {@link kOFFSET_URL kOFFSET_URL}: This offset represents the institute list of URLs or web pages.

The object is considered {@link _IsInited() initialised} only if it has its {@link Code() code}, as its {@link CEntity ancestor}, its {@link Name() name}, {@link Password() password} and {@link Email() e-mail} address.

If the {@link Code() code} has not been explicitly set, {@link _PrepareCommit() before} {@link Commit() committing} the object it will be set to the value of the {@link Email e-mail}. Also in that phase, the {@link kENTITY_USER kENTITY_USER} constant will be set in the user {@link Type() type}.

The {@link Email() e-mail} in this class is a scalar property, in other classes it will probably be a list of different e-mail types. In this class we want to link a single user with a single e-mail, possibly not shared by any other user, that is why we link by default the user {@link Code() code} and {@link Email() e-mail}.

The unique identifier of this class is composed by the default {@link _index() index} of thew object, prefixed by the {@link kENTITY_INST kENTITY_INST} token and the {@link kTOKEN_CLASS_SEPARATOR kTOKEN_CLASS_SEPARATOR} token, this allows institutes and other types of {@link CEntity entities} to share the same {@link Code() code}; this is enforced both in the {@link HashIndex() HashIndex} method, to which you only need to pass the user {@link Code() code}, and in the protected {@link _PrepareCommit() _PrepareCommit} method which will place the resulting string in the global {@link kTAG_GID identifier}.

We {@link CEntity::__construct() overload} the constructor to initialise the {@link _IsInited() inited} {@link kFLAG_STATE_INITED flag} if the {@link Name() name} element is set.

We also enforce the {@link _IsEncoded() encoded} {@link kFLAG_STATE_ENCODED flag}.

This method can be used to handle the institute {@link kOFFSET_ACRONYM acronyms} list, it uses the standard accessor {@link CAttribute::ManageArrayOffset() method} to manage the list of acronyms.

Each element of this list should indicate an acronym by which one refers to the current institute, the nature and specifics of these elements is the responsibility of concrete classes.

For a more thorough reference of how this method works, please consult the {@link CAttribute::ManageArrayOffset() CAttribute::ManageArrayOffset} method, in which the second parameter will be the constant {@link kOFFSET_ACRONYM kOFFSET_ACRONYM}.

This method can be used to manage the institute {@link kOFFSET_URL URL} or web pages list, the method expects the following parameters:

  • $theValue: The value or operation:
    • NULL: Return the current value selected by the second parameter.
    • FALSE: Delete the value selected by the second parameter.
    • other: Set value selected by the second parameter.
  • $theType: The element type, kind or index:
    • NULL: This value indicates that the URL has no type or kind, in general, when adding elements, this case applies to default elements.
    • other: All other types will be interpreted as the kind or type of the URL.
  • $getOld: Determines what the method will return:
    • TRUE: Return the value before it was eventually modified.
    • FALSE: Return the value after it was eventually modified.

This method can be used to format an identifier provided as a string, it will be used by the {@link _id() _id} method to format the result of the {@link _index() _index} method. One can consider this as the index hashing method for all derived classes.

In this class we take the provided {@link Code() code} and prefix it with the {@link kENTITY_INST kENTITY_INST} token, the result will be {@link CDataTypeBinary hashed}

docblock.description: Set a value for a given offset.
docblock.long-description: We overload this method to manage the {@link _IsInited() inited} {@link kFLAG_STATE_INITED status}: this is set if the {@link kTAG_NAME name}, {@link kOFFSET_EMAIL e-mail}, {@link kOFFSET_PASSWORD password} and the parent {@link kTAG_CODE code} are set.

docblock.description: Reset a value for a given offset.
docblock.long-description: We overload this method to manage the {@link _IsInited() inited} {@link kFLAG_STATE_INITED status}: this is set if the {@link kTAG_NAME name}, {@link kOFFSET_EMAIL e-mail}, {@link kOFFSET_PASSWORD password} and the parent {@link kTAG_CODE code} are set.

We overload this method to initialise the {@link kENTITY_INST kENTITY_INST} {@link Type() type} to the object prior {@link Commit() saving} it.

We also force the {@link _IsEncoded() encoded} {@link kFLAG_STATE_ENCODED flag}.

This class implements a mailing address, it wraps the {@link CArrayObject parent} class around a structure that defines a mailing address.

In general instances of this class will be embedded in {@link CPersistentObject persistent} objects to add lists of addresses, the current class does not feature any persistence functions, it only concentrates in managing an address as a set of properties:

  • {@link Place() Place}: This {@link kOFFSET_PLACE property} defines a named place or location, it should be used only if required.
  • {@link Care() Care} of: This {@link kOFFSET_CARE property} indicates who is the owner or reference at the address that is not the same as the sender. It should be used only if required.
  • {@link Street() Street}: This {@link kOFFSET_STREET property} indicates the street name or P.O. box number.
  • {@link Zip() Zip}: This {@link kOFFSET_ZIP_CODE property} indicates the ZIP code.
  • {@link City() City}: This {@link kOFFSET_CITY property} indicates the address city name.
  • {@link Province() Province}: This {@link kOFFSET_PROVINCE property} indicates the address province name or code.
  • {@link Country() Country}: This {@link kOFFSET_COUNTRY property} indicates the address country name or code.
  • {@link Full() Full} address: This {@link kOFFSET_FULL property} can be used when an address does not have its properties separated, or it can be used as an export feature.

The constructor will instantiate an object either from an array, by loading all corresponding properties, from a string, in which case it will be interpreted as the {@link Full() full} address, or as an empty address.

This method can be used to manage the address {@link kOFFSET_PLACE place}, it accepts a parameter which represents either the place name or the requested operation, depending on its value:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method can be used to manage the address {@link kOFFSET_CARE care-of}, it accepts a parameter which represents a care-of reference or the requested operation, depending on its value:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method can be used to manage the address {@link kOFFSET_STREET street}, it accepts a parameter which represents a street name, P.O. box or the requested operation, depending on its value:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method can be used to manage the address {@link kOFFSET_ZIP_CODE zip} code, it accepts a parameter which represents the address zip code or the requested operation, depending on its value:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method can be used to manage the address {@link kOFFSET_CITY city}, it accepts a parameter which represents the address city name or the requested operation, depending on its value:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method can be used to manage the address {@link kOFFSET_PROVINCE province}, it accepts a parameter which represents the address province name, code or the requested operation, depending on its value:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method can be used to manage the address {@link kOFFSET_COUNTRY country}, it accepts a parameter which represents the address country name, code or the requested operation, depending on its value:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method can be used to manage the full address as a {@link kOFFSET_FULL string}, it accepts a parameter which represents the full address or the requested operation, depending on its value:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

When retrieving values, if the full address was not set, this method will return in any case the string representation of the full address.

This class extends its {@link CContainer ancestor} to implement an object store based on MongoCollection containers.

This method should return the current container's name.

In this class we return the collection name.
We {@link CContainer::Container() overload} this method to ensure that the provided container is a MongoCollection object.
In this class we return the collection's database.

We {@link CContainer::UnserialiseData() implement} this method to convert all standard {@link CDataType types} into custom Mongo data types.

In this class we parse the following types and {@link kTAG_TYPE offsets}:

  • {@link CDataTypeMongoId CDataTypeMongoId} object or {@link kTYPE_MongoId kTYPE_MongoId} offset: We return a MongoId object.
  • {@link CDataTypeMongoCode CDataTypeMongoCode} object or {@link kTYPE_MongoCode kTYPE_MongoCode} offset: We return a MongoCode object.
  • {@link CDataTypeStamp CDataTypeStamp} object or {@link kTYPE_STAMP kTYPE_STAMP} offset: We return a MongoDate object.
  • {@link CDataTypeRegex CDataTypeRegex} object or {@link kTYPE_REGEX kTYPE_REGEX} offset: We return a MongoRegex object.
  • {@link CDataTypeInt32 CDataTypeInt32} object or {@link kTYPE_INT32 kTYPE_INT32} offset: We return a MongoInt32 object.
  • {@link CDataTypeInt64 CDataTypeInt64} object or {@link kTYPE_INT64 kTYPE_INT64} offset: We return a MongoInt64 object.
  • {@link CDataTypeBinary CDataTypeBinary} object or {@link kTYPE_BINARY kTYPE_BINARY} offset: We return a MongoBinData object.

We implement this method to handle MongoCollection object stores, this method will store the object in the current container.

The method will check if the current container is a MongoCollection, if this is not the case, it will raise an {@link kERROR_INVALID_STATE exception}.

If the provided modifiers indicate a {@link kFLAG_PERSIST_MODIFY modify} operation, the method will return the modified object, in all other cases the method will return the object identifier.

We implement this method to handle MongoCollection object stores, this method will retrieve the object from the current container.

The {@link Load() caller} will have resolved references andeventually extracted the identifier from the provided parameter.

If the provided parameter is an array, the method will assume it is a query; if not, the method will assume it is the value to match against the {@link kTAG_LID local} identifier.

The method will use the findOne method to retrieve the object.
We implement this method to handle MongoCollection object stores, this method will remove the object from the current container.

We {@link CContainer::_PrepareCommit() overload} this method to handle the identifier: if provided, it means that that is to become the object's unique {@link kTAG_LID identifier}; if not provided and the object has an {@link kTAG_LID identifier}, we use that one.

We also raise an exception if the provided object is not either an array or an ArrayObject.

The duty of this method is to ensure that the parameters provided to the {@link _Load() find} operation are valid.

In this class we {@link CContainer::_PrepareLoad() overload} this method to handle identifiers provided as queries.
This is the tag that represents the findOne Mongo operation, it will return the first matched object.

This tag defines a web service that returns an object by reference. It is equivalent to the {@link kAPI_OP_GET_ONE kAPI_OP_GET_ONE} operation, except that instead of using the query provided in the {@link kAPI_DATA_QUERY kAPI_DATA_QUERY} parameter, it will try to extract an identifier from the object provided in the {@link kAPI_DATA_OBJECT kAPI_DATA_OBJECT} parameter.

Note that as with other values in the {@link kAPI_DATA_OBJECT object} parameter, you must {@link CDataType::SerialiseObject() serialise} the value.
This tag will hold the native status of the operation.
This tag will hold the total number of elements affected by the operation.

Can be a boolean or integer, defaults to FALSE. If TRUE, the {@link kAPI_DATA_RESPONSE response} section will not be included in the result. This can be useful when you are only interested in the status of the operation and not in the response.

This class overloads its {@link CDataWrapper ancestor} to implement a web-service that uses a MongoDB data store to manage objects.

This class implements the various elements declared in its {@link CDataWrapper ancestor} and adds the following options:

  • {@link kAPI_OP_GET_ONE kAPI_OP_GET_ONE}: This {@link kAPI_OPERATION operation} is equivalent to the {@link kAPI_OP_GET kAPI_OP_GET} operation, except that it will only return the first found element. It is equivalent to the Mongo findOne() method.
  • {@link kAPI_OP_GET_OBJECT_REF kAPI_OP_GET_OBJECT_REF}: This {@link kAPI_OPERATION operation} will return an object referenced by an identifier provided in the {@link kAPI_DATA_OBJECT kAPI_DATA_OBJECT} parameter. It is equivalent to the {@link kAPI_OP_GET_ONE kAPI_OP_GET_ONE} operation, except that instead of using the query provided in the {@link kAPI_DATA_QUERY kAPI_DATA_QUERY} parameter, it will try to extract an identifier from the object provided in the {@link kAPI_DATA_OBJECT kAPI_DATA_OBJECT} parameter. Remember to {@link CDataType::SerialiseObject() serialise} the reference before providing it to the wrapper.

This class also implements a static interface that can be used to {@link UnserialiseObject() unserialise} data flowing to and from the service parameters and the Mongo container.
In this class we initialise the Mongo object into the {@link kSESSION_MONGO kSESSION_MONGO} offset of the $_SESSION variable.
We overload this method to parse the no {@link kAPI_OPT_NO_RESP response} tag.

This method should perform any needed formatting before the request will be handled.

In this class we handle the parameters to be decoded

This method should check that the request is valid and that all required parameters have been sent.

In this class we check if the provided {@link kAPI_DATA_OBJECT object} contains the {@link kTAG_REFERENCE_ID identifier} when executing tree functions.
This method will parse the no response operation.

This method will format the request database.

In this class we set the database to a MongoDB object.

This method will format the request container.

In this class we set the request container to a MongoCollection object.

This method will format the request query.

In this class we set the query to a CMongoQuery object.

This method will format the request object.

In this class we resolve the Mongo native types.

This method can be used to check whether the provided {@link kAPI_OPERATION operation} parameter is valid.

In this class, if the query was omitted and an object reference was required, we check if the object {@link kTAG_LID native} identifier is there: in that case we compile the query with that value.
This method can be used to check whether the provided {@link kAPI_DATA_OBJECT object} contains the {@link kTAG_REFERENCE_ID identifier} when executing tree functions.

This method can be used to check whether the provided {@link kAPI_DATA_QUERY query} parameter is valid.

In this class we convert the query to the native Mongo format.
This method will handle the request.
This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_HELP kAPI_OP_HELP} request, which should return the list of supported operations.

This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_GET_OBJECT_REF kAPI_OP_GET_OBJECT_REF} request, which returns an object corresponding to the object {@link CMongoObjectReference reference} provided in the {@link kAPI_DATA_OBJECT object} parameter.
This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_COUNT kAPI_OP_COUNT} request, which returns the total count of a Mongo query.
This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_GET_ONE kAPI_OP_GET_ONE} request, which corresponds to the findOne Mongo query.
This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_GET kAPI_OP_GET} request, which corresponds to the find Mongo query.
This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_GET kAPI_OP_GET} request, which corresponds to the find Mongo query.
This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_SET kAPI_OP_SET} request, which will insert/update the provided object.
This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_INSERT kAPI_OP_INSERT} request, which will insert the provided object.
This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_BATCH_INSERT kAPI_OP_BATCH_INSERT} request, which will insert the provided list of objects.
This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_UPDATE kAPI_OP_UPDATE} request, which will update the provided object.

This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_MODIFY kAPI_OP_MODIFY} request, which will update the provided object.

The data provided in the {@link kAPI_DATA_OBJECT object} parameter will be scanned and all NULL values will be set in the $unset array and the non NULL values in the $set array.

This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_DEL kAPI_OP_DEL} request, whichwill delete all objects matching the provided filter.

The method expects the justOne parameter in the provided {@link kAPI_DATA_OPTIONS options}, if not provided, it will default to FALSE.

This method will be called before serialising the result if {@link kAPI_DATA_OPTIONS options} are provided in the request.

In this class we don't do anything, derived classes should handle specific elements.

This class represents a MongoDB web-services data wrapper client, it facilitates the job of requesting information from servers derived from the {@link CMongoDataWrapper CMongoDataWrapper} class.

This class adds the following properties to its {@link CWrapperClient ancestor}:

  • {@link NoResponse() No} response: This {@link kAPI_OPT_NO_RESP property} represents a switch that, if on, prevents the response from being sent. This can be useful when you are only interested in the status of the operation and not in the response.

The class also adds the following new operations:

  • {@link kAPI_OP_GET_ONE kAPI_OP_GET_ONE}: This is the tag that represents the findOne Mongo operation, it will return the first matched object.
  • {@link kAPI_OP_GET_OBJECT_REF kAPI_OP_GET_OBJECT_REF}: This tag defines a web service that returns an object by reference. It is equivalent to the {@link kAPI_OP_GET_ONE kAPI_OP_GET_ONE} operation, except that instead of using the query provided in the {@link kAPI_DATA_QUERY kAPI_DATA_QUERY} parameter, it will try to extract an identifier from the object provided in the {@link kAPI_DATA_OBJECT kAPI_DATA_OBJECT} parameter.

We {@link CDataWrapperClient::Operation() overload} this method to add the following allowed operations:

  • {@link kAPI_OP_GET_ONE kAPI_OP_GET_ONE}: This is the tag that represents the findOne Mongo operation, it will return the first matched object.
  • {@link kAPI_OP_GET_OBJECT_REF kAPI_OP_GET_OBJECT_REF}: This tag defines a web-service that returns an object by reference. It is equivalent to the {@link kAPI_OP_GET_ONE kAPI_OP_GET_ONE} operation, except that instead of using the query provided in the {@link kAPI_DATA_QUERY kAPI_DATA_QUERY} parameter, it will try to extract an identifier from the object provided in the {@link kAPI_DATA_OBJECT kAPI_DATA_OBJECT} parameter.

This method can be used to manage the no {@link kAPI_OPT_NO_RESP response} switch, it accepts a boolean which represents either the on/off value, or the requested operation:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This class extends its {@link CMongoContainer ancestor} to implement a file store based on MongoGridFS containers.
We {@link CMongoContainer::Container() overload} this method to ensure that the provided container is a MongoGridFS object.

We {@link CMongoContainer::Commit() overload} this method to handle committing files as opposed to documents. We handle the provided parameters as follows:

  • $theObject: This parameter represents the file to be stored:
    • SplFileInfo: In this case the parameter is interpreted as a file path, it will be resolved with the getRealPath() method.
    • other: In all other cases the parameter is interpreted as the file contents provided as a binary string.
  • $theIdentifier: If provided, this parameter is interpreted as the file's metadata and will be enclosed in an array labeled metadata.
  • $theModifiers: This parameter is initialised to {@link kFLAG_PERSIST_INSERT kFLAG_PERSIST_INSERT}, since this is the default and only operation possible.

The method will return the object's key within the container or raise an exception if the operation was not successful.

The only reason to overload this method is to write this documentation and set the default modifier, there is no functional difference between this method and its {@link CMongoContainer::Commit() inherited} version.

We implement this method to handle MongoGridFS object stores, this method will store the object in the current container.

This particular container type only supports creating new records, that is, files are added to the grid and cannot be modified. Also, files can be added either by path or by content, depending on the provided object parameter.

The parameters accepted by this method are:

  • &$theObject: This parameter holds the file to be added:
    • SplFileInfo: In this case the parameter is interpreted as a file path, it will be resolved with the getRealPath() method.
    • other: In all other cases the parameter is interpreted as the file contents provided as a binary string.
  • $theIdentifier: This parameter is interpreted as the file's metadata and has been normalised before this method.
  • $theModifiers: We ignore this parameter.

The

We {@link CMongoContainer::_PrepareCommit() override} this method to reset the parameters that are not relevant to the operation, that is, we set the identifier to an empty array if NULL or enclose it in a metadata array if not and force the modifiers to {@link kFLAG_PERSIST_INSERT kFLAG_PERSIST_INSERT}.

We also check if the native container is of the correct type.

Note that we do not call the parent method, but the grandpa method explicitly.

This class extends its {@link CQuery ancestor} to implement a public method that will convert the current object's query into a query suitable to be submitted to a Mongo database.

The method will return an array suitable to be provided as a MongoDB query, the method requires a container that will take care of converting query arguments to native data types, this container must be an instance of {@link CMongoContainer CMongoContainer}, or the method will raise an exception.

This method expects a condition as its argument, it will check if it is a valid condition, then it will {@link _ValidateStatement() validate} all condition statements.

In this class we handle queries to Mongo databases, so the depth of the query conditions cannot go beyond 2 levels.

We overload this method to prevent nesting OR conditions.

This method will convert the statements of the provided condition to Mongo format.

The parameters to this method are:

  • &$theQuery: Reference to an array that will receive the converted condition.
  • $theContainer: Data container, must be derived from {@link CMongoContainer CMongoContainer}.
  • $theCondition: Boolean condition code.
  • $theStatements: List of condition statements.

This method will convert the statement to Mongo format.

The parameters to this method are:

  • &$theQuery: Reference to an array that will receive the converted statement.
  • $theContainer: Data container, must be derived from {@link CMongoContainer CMongoContainer} and we assume this check has been done by the {@link _ConvertCondition() caller}.
  • $theCondition: Boolean condition code.
  • $theStatement: Statement.

This method will order the provided range elements, the method accepts an array of two elements which represent the range bounds and will return an array with the two provided elements sorted.

The method accepts three parameters:

  • $theRange: An array containing two elements representing the range bounds.
  • $theContainer: The {@link CMongoContainer container} on which the query will be executed.
  • $theType: The data type of the range elements.

The method expects the range elements to be in {@link CDataType::SerialiseData() serialised} format, these elements will be {@link CContainer::UnserialiseData() converted} by this method which will return them in sorted order.

This abstract class implements a common interface shared by all classes in this library.

The library uses the following conventions:

Naming standards

  • Classes: All class names in this library start with a capital (C), for instance CAnotherClass, followed by a name starting with another capital letter.
  • Public methods: All public method names should begin with a capital letter, for instance AnotherMethod().
  • Protected and private methods: All protected and private method names should begin with an underscore, for instance _AnotherMethod(). Another case in which names would start with an underscore is with core static methods.
  • Members: All members should start with lowercase (m), followed by a capital letter. For instance mMember.
  • Static members: All static members should begin with lowercase (s), so a static member could be CSomeClass::$sStaticMember.
  • Definitions: All definitions should start with a (k) and be followed by a code and ending with an uppercase name, for instance kTAG_DOMAIN would be the definition of a domain tag.
  • Method arguments: All method arguments should start with either the, for parameters holding miscellaneous values, such as $theVariable,, or with a lowercase verb, such as is, has or do, for parameters holding a flag value, such as isProtected.
  • Local variables: All local variables should be in lowercase, for instance $local_counter.

In general, abstract classes implement public interfaces which call a protected implementation. Usually the public methods should not be overridden, while derived classes may implement custom behaviours in the protected interface.

This class implements the following interfaces:

  • Offsets: In this class there cannot be an offset with a NULL value, the offset itself should be {@link offsetUnset() deleted} in that case. Because of this we also override the inherited behaviour by suppressing notices and warnings when {@link offsetGet() getting} non-existant offsets.
  • JSON encoding: Derived classes will use JSON for web-services, so we provide two static methods to {@link JsonEncode() encode} and {@link JsonDecode() decode} JSON strings allowing for exceptions on errors.
  • String formatting: We provide a generalised static method to {@link StringNormalise() format} strings which accepts a bitfield parameter that indicates which operation to perform, such as {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8 UTF8} encode, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_LTRIM left} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_RTRIM right} trim, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULL NULL} handling, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NOCASE case} insensitive conversion, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_URL URL}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HTML HTML} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEX HEX} encoding and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HASH hashing}.
  • Time formatting: We provide a generalised static {@link DurationString() method} to display duration strings.
This method will return the provided array or object into a JSON encoded string.
This method will return an array representation of the provided JSON string.

This method can be used to format a string, the provided modifiers bitfield determines what manipulations are applied:

  • {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8 kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8}: Convert the string to the UTF8 character set.
  • {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_LTRIM kFLAG_MODIFIER_LTRIM}: Apply left trimming to the string.
  • {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_RTRIM kFLAG_MODIFIER_RTRIM}: Apply right trimming to the string.
  • {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_TRIM kFLAG_MODIFIER_TRIM}: Apply both left and right trimming to the string.
  • {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULL kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULL}: If this flag is set and the resulting string is empty, the method will return NULL.
    • {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULLSTR kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULLSTR}: If this flag is set and the resulting string is empty, the method will return the 'NULL' string; this option implies that the {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULL kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULL} is also set.
  • {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NOCASE kFLAG_MODIFIER_NOCASE}: Set the string to lowercase, this is the default way to generate a case insensitive string.
  • {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_URL kFLAG_MODIFIER_URL}: URL-encode the string; note that this option and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HTML kFLAG_MODIFIER_HTML} are mutually exclusive.
  • {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HTML kFLAG_MODIFIER_HTML}: HTML-encode the string; note that this option and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_URL kFLAG_MODIFIER_URL} are mutually exclusive.
  • {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEX kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEX}: Convert the string to hexadecimal; note that this option and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_MASK_HASH hashing} are mutually exclusive.
    • {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEXEXP kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEXEXP}: Convert the string to a hexadecimal expression; note that this option implies {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEX kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEX}, and this option and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_MASK_HASH hashing} are mutually exclusive.
  • {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HASH kFLAG_MODIFIER_HASH}: If this bit is set the resulting string will be hashed using the md5 algorithm resulting in a 32 character hexadecimal string; this option is mutually exclusive with the {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_MASK_HEX kFLAG_MODIFIER_MASK_HEX} option.
    • {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HASH_BIN kFLAG_MODIFIER_HASH_BIN}: If this bit is set, the resulting value should be a 16 character binary string; if the bit is OFF, the resulting value should be a 32 character hexadecimal string.

The order in which these modifications are applied are as stated.

This function will return a formatted duration string in H:MM:SS:mmmmm format, where H stands for hours, M stands for minutes, S stands for seconds and m stands for milliseconds, from the value of microtime( TRUE ).

Note: The provided value should be a difference between two timestamps taken with microtime( true ).

This library implements a standard interface for managing object properties using methods, this method implements this interface:

  • $theMember: The member to manage, it is a reference to the element being managed.
  • $theValue: The value or operation:
    • NULL: Return the member's current value.
    • FALSE: Reset the member, NULL by default.
    • other: Any other type represents the member's new value.
  • $getOld: Determines what the method will return:
    • TRUE: Return the value of the member before it was eventually modified.
    • FALSE: Return the value of the member after it was eventually modified.

This class implements an ontology graph edge node.

The class is derived from {@link CGraphEdge CGraphEdge} and implements the exact same functionality as {@link COntologyNode COntologyNode}, it adds two elements: the {@link SubjectTerm() subject} and {@link ObjectTerm() object} {@link COntologyTerm terms} which are linked with the {@link Subject() subject} and {@link Object() object} nodes.

Instances of this class represent predicate nodes and they hold the referenced nodes.
This data member holds the node predicate {@link COntologyTerm term}.

We {@link CGraphEdge::_Commit() overload} this method to provide the correct container to the {@link CGraphEdge parent} {@link CGraphEdge::_Commit() method}.

We also {@link COntologyTerm::Commit() commit} the {@link SubjectTerm() subject} and {@link ObjectTerm() object} {@link COntologyTerm terms}, setting or removing {@link COntologyTerm their} {@link kTAG_NODEnode} reference.

We also overload this method to store the node properties into a Mongo collection named {@link kDEFAULT_CNT_EDGES kDEFAULT_CNT_EDGES}, the record will be indexed by the combination of subject and node IDs interleaved with the predicate term {@link kTAG_GID identifier} and divided by the {@link kTOKEN_INDEX_SEPARATOR kTOKEN_INDEX_SEPARATOR} token.
In this class we pass the correct parameters to the {@link CGraphEdge parent} {@link CGraphEdge::_Load() method}.

In this class we first check whether the container has the following structure:

  • {@link kTAG_NODE kTAG_NODE}: This element should hold the nodes container, it must be a Everyman\Neo4j\Client instance.
  • {@link kTAG_TERM kTAG_TERM}: This element should hold the terms container, it must be a {@link CContainer CContainer} instance.

If the container has the correct structure the {@link kTAG_NODE node} container will be passed to the parent method and the method will check if the {@link kTAG_TERM term} container is a {@link COntologyTermObject COntologyTermObject}.
In this class we check if the provided container is supported., terms require a container instance derived from {@link CContainer CContainer}.
In this class we check if the provided container is supported and we set the {@link kTAG_TERM term} property in the node and {@link Commit() commit} the {@link Term() term}.
In this class we initialise the {@link Term() predicate}, {@link SubjectTerm() subject} and {@link ObjectTerm() object} {@link COntologyTerm terms}.

In this class we get the term reference from the node {@link Type() type} property and load it, along with the {@link Subject() subject} and {@link Object() object} terms.

Note that if the object has a {@link Type() type} it means it was read from the container: in this case it must have term references for both the {@link SubjectTerm() subject} and {@link ObjectTerm() object}, or an exception should be raised.

This method will save node indexes after the node was {@link _Commit() committed}, it will perform the following selections:

  • {@link kINDEX_EDGE_TERM kINDEX_EDGE_TERM}: The {@link Term() term} {@link kTAG_GID global} identifier (RelationshipIndex). container, it must be a Everyman\Neo4j\Client instance.
  • {@link kINDEX_EDGE_NAME kINDEX_EDGE_NAME}: The {@link Term() term} {@link COntologyTermObject::Name() names} in all languages (RelationshipIndex).
  • {@link kINDEX_EDGE_TERMS kINDEX_EDGE_TERMS}: The node relations, this index records the relation terms, that is, the combination of the subject {@link SubjectTerm() term}, predicate {@link Term() term} and the object {@link ObjectTerm() term}, this can be used to retrieve existing relations.

The following index tags are set:

  • {@link kTAG_GID kTAG_GID}: The {@link Term() term} {@link kTAG_GID global} identifier.
  • {@link kTAG_NAME kTAG_NAME}: The {@link Term() term} {@link kTAG_NAME names}.
  • {@link kTAG_EDGE_TERM kTAG_EDGE_TERM}: The relationships between terms taken from the {@link Node() node}'s {@link kTAG_EDGE_TERM kTAG_EDGE_TERM} property, formatted as a SUBJECT/PREDICATE/OBJECT string, in which each element is the {@link kTAG_GID global} {@link COntologyTerm term} identifier.
  • {@link kTAG_NODE kTAG_NODE}: The relationships between {@link Node() nodes}, expressed as a SUBJECT/PREDICATE/OBJECT string, in which the subject and object are the {@link Node() node} identifiers and the predicate is the {@link kTAG_GID global} {@link Term() term} identifier.
This method can be used to return an edge index identified by the provided index tag.

This class implements a graph edge node index, it can be used to replicate a Neo4j edge node to a MongoDB collection.

Neo4j uses Lucene as its standard indexing tool, in this library we use MongoDB as the standard database, so it is a logical choice to use Mongo as the indexing mechanism for Neo4j. Also, by storing nodes in Mongo, by dumping the database contents we also have the graph structure with it.

The class features a single data member, the {@link Node() node} which contains a Neo4j edge node reference. When {@link __construct() instantiating} this class you are required to provide a persistent instance of a node.

The contents of the object will be the node properties as will be stored in the Mongo {@link kDEFAULT_CNT_EDGES default} collection for edges:

  • {@link kTAG_LID kTAG_LID}: This offset will hold the edge node ID.
  • {@link kTAG_PATH kTAG_PATH}: This offset will hold the edge node path, that is, the source node ID, the predicate term {@link kTAG_GID identifier} and the object node ID, all three separated by the {@link kTOKEN_INDEX_SEPARATOR kTOKEN_INDEX_SEPARATOR} token.
  • {@link kTAG_SUBJECT kTAG_SUBJECT}: This offset will hold the subject node information:
    • {@link kTAG_TERM kTAG_TERM}: The subject node term {@link kTAG_GID identifier}.
    • {@link kTAG_NODE kTAG_NODE}: The subject node ID.
  • {@link kTAG_PREDICATE kTAG_PREDICATE}: This offset will hold the predicate information:
    • {@link kTAG_TERM kTAG_TERM}: The predicate term {@link kTAG_GID identifier}, which corresponds to the edge node type.
    • {@link kTAG_NODE kTAG_NODE}: The edge node ID.
  • {@link kTAG_OBJECT kTAG_OBJECT}: This offset will hold the object node information:
    • {@link kTAG_TERM kTAG_TERM}: The object node term {@link kTAG_GID identifier}.
    • {@link kTAG_NODE kTAG_NODE}: The object node ID.
  • {@link kTAG_DATA kTAG_DATA}: This offset will hold the edge node properties.

The class provides a single member accessor method: {@link Node() Node}, which can be used to set the referenced edge node.

Note that the class will not cast to an array correctly, you must use the {@link getArrayCopy() getArrayCopy} method to get an array, if you know how to solve this, please do it!
We {@link COntologyNodeIndex::Node() overload} this method to ensure that the provided node is an edge node.

The edge path represents the unique identifier of an edge node using the relationship node identifiers, it is composed by the subject and object node IDs and the predicate term identifier.

This method will return the {@link kTAG_PATH path} according to the provided parameters:

  • $theSubject: The relation subject node reference:
    • {@link COntologyNode COntologyNode}: The node ID will be used.
    • Neo4j node: The node ID will be used.
    • other: Other types will be cast to a string.
  • $thePredicate: The relation predicate term reference, the value will be cast to a string and is expected to represent the {@link COntologyTerm term} {@link kTAG_GID global} identifier.
  • $theObject: The relation object node reference:
    • {@link COntologyNode COntologyNode}: The node ID will be used.
    • Neo4j node: The node ID will be used.
    • other: Other types will be cast to a string.

The method will check if all three parameters are not empty, if this is not the case, the method will raise an exception.

This edge path represents an identifier of an edge node using the relationship term identifiers, it is composed by the subject, predicate and object term {@link kTAG_GID identifiers}.

This method will return the {@link kTAG_EDGE_TERM path} according to the provided parameters:

  • $theSubject: The relation subject term reference, the value will be cast to a string and is expected to represent the {@link COntologyTerm term} {@link kTAG_GID global} identifier.
  • $thePredicate: The relation predicate term reference, the value will be cast to a string and is expected to represent the {@link COntologyTerm term} {@link kTAG_GID global} identifier.
  • $theObject: The relation object node reference, the value will be cast to a string and is expected to represent the {@link COntologyTerm term} {@link kTAG_GID global} identifier.

The method will check if all three parameters are not empty, if this is not the case, the method will raise an exception.
We {@link COntologyNodeIndex::_ResolveIndexContainer() overload} this class to use the correct {@link kDEFAULT_CNT_EDGES default} collection when providing a MongoDB.

We {@link COntologyNodeIndex::_LocateNode() overload} this method to locate relationships in place of nodes.

We also override the rule of raising an exception on zero node IDs, because the first relationship will have an ID of zero, here we check if the identifier is numeric.

Finally, we handle arrays in the node parameter: in this case we assume the array holds the subject node ID, the predicate term {@link kTAG_GID identifier} and the object node ID, these elements will be used to select the edge node whose {@link kTAG_PATH kTAG_PATH} offset corresponds to this combination. In this case the provided container must be an array structured as follows:

  • {@link kTAG_NODE kTAG_NODE}: The graph container.
  • {@link kTAG_TERM kTAG_TERM}: The index container.

We {@link COntologyNodeIndex::_LocateNode() overload} this method to load the edge node properties along with the subject, predicate and object information as follows:

  • {@link kTAG_LID kTAG_LID}: This offset will hold the edge node ID.
  • {@link kTAG_PATH kTAG_PATH}: This offset will hold the edge node path, that is, the source node ID, the predicate term {@link kTAG_GID identifier} and the object node ID, all three separated by the {@link kTOKEN_INDEX_SEPARATOR kTOKEN_INDEX_SEPARATOR} token.
  • {@link kTAG_SUBJECT kTAG_SUBJECT}: This offset will hold the subject node information:
    • {@link kTAG_TERM kTAG_TERM}: The subject node term {@link kTAG_GID identifier}.
    • {@link kTAG_NODE kTAG_NODE}: The subject node ID.
  • {@link kTAG_PREDICATE kTAG_PREDICATE}: This offset will hold the predicate information:
    • {@link kTAG_TERM kTAG_TERM}: The predicate term {@link kTAG_GID identifier}, which corresponds to the edge node type.
    • {@link kTAG_NODE kTAG_NODE}: The edge node ID.
  • {@link kTAG_OBJECT kTAG_OBJECT}: This offset will hold the object node information:
    • {@link kTAG_TERM kTAG_TERM}: The object node term {@link kTAG_GID identifier}.
    • {@link kTAG_NODE kTAG_NODE}: The object node ID.
  • {@link kTAG_DATA kTAG_DATA}: This offset will hold the edge node properties.

This method will increment or decrement the relationships count in the subject and object {node indexes.

The method accepts the following parameters:

  • $theContainer: The index Mongo container, we use the {@link CMongoContainer::Database() database} element and force the {@link kDEFAULT_CNT_NODES default} node collection name, since it apparently gives this class personality disorder problems to use the parent version of the {@link _ResolveIndexContainer() _ResolveIndexContainer} method.
  • $theModifiers: This parameter represents the commit operation options, these will have been passed by the {@link Commit() commit} method.

These counts are stored in the {@link COntologyNodeIndex indexes} in the following structure:

  • {@link kTAG_IN kTAG_IN}: This element represents incoming relationships, it is an array structured as follows:
    • Key: The term {@link kTAG_GID identifier} of the relationship predicate.
    • Value: The number of incoming relationships for the given predicate.
  • {@link kTAG_OUT kTAG_OUT}: This element represents outgoing relationships, it is an array structured as follows:
    • Key: The term {@link kTAG_GID identifier} of the relationship predicate.
    • Value: The number of outgoing relationships for the given predicate.

This tag defines the index (NodeIndex) collecting ontology node term references. This index will link the node to the term via the following keys:

  • {@link kTAG_TERM kTAG_TERM}: This key links the current node to the node's {@link COntologyTerm term} {@link kTAG_GID identifiers}.
  • {@link kTAG_NAME kTAG_NAME}: This key links the current node to the node's {@link COntologyTerm term} {@link kTAG_NAME names}.

This tag defines the index (NodeIndex) collecting ontology node properties. This index will link the node to its properties via the following keys:

  • {@link kTAG_TYPE kTAG_TYPE}: This key links the current node to its {@link COntologyNode::Type() type}, which may either be inherited from its {@link COntologyNode::Term() term} or have been {@link COntologyNode::Type() explicitly} set.
  • {@link kTAG_KIND kTAG_KIND}: This key links the current node to its {@link COntologyNode::Kind() kinds}, which may either be inherited from its {@link COntologyNode::Term() term} or have been {@link COntologyNode::Kind() explicitly} set.
  • {@link kTAG_DOMAIN kTAG_DOMAIN}: This key links the current node to its {@link COntologyNode::Domain() domains}, which may either be inherited from its {@link COntologyNode::Term() term} or have been {@link COntologyNode::Domain() explicitly} set.
  • {@link kTAG_CATEGORY kTAG_CATEGORY}: This key links the current node to its {@link COntologyNode::Category() categories}, which may either be inherited from its {@link COntologyNode::Category() term} or have been {@link COntologyNode::Category() explicitly} set.

This class implements an ontology graph node.

The class is derived from {@link CGraphNode CGraphNode}, it adds another required property, the {@link Term() term}. This class will wrap the array access framework to the combination of the {@link Node() node} properties and the {@link Term() term} elements, except that the {@link Term() term} elements will be read-only.

This class introduces a new kind of container: it must be an array of two elements structured as follows:

  • {@link kTAG_NODE kTAG_NODE}: This element should hold the nodes container, it must be a Everyman\Neo4j\Client instance.
  • {@link kTAG_TERM kTAG_TERM}: This element should hold the terms container, it must be a {@link CContainer CContainer} instance.

Note that the class will not cast to an array correctly, you must use the {@link getArrayCopy() getArrayCopy} method to get an array, if you know how to solve this, please do it!
This data member holds the node {@link COntologyTerm term}.
In this class we return the {@link Term() term} {@link Node() node} {@link kTAG_TERM property}.

This method can be used to manage the node term reference, it uses the standard accessor {@link CObject::ManageMember() method} to manage the property:

  • $theValue: The value or operation:
    • NULL: Return the current value.
    • FALSE: Delete the value.
    • {@link COntologyTermObject COntologyTermObject}: Set value.
    • other: Raise exception.
  • $getOld: Determines what the method will return:
    • TRUE: Return the value before it was eventually modified.
    • FALSE: Return the value after it was eventually modified.

The method will also set the {@link _IsDirty() dirty} {@link kFLAG_STATE_DIRTY status} and the {@link _IsInited() inited} {@link kFLAG_STATE_INITED status} if the node is provided.

This method can be used to manage the node {@link kTAG_KIND kinds}, in general it reflects the {@link Term() term} {@link CCodedUnitObject::Kind() kinds}.

For a more thorough reference of how this method works, please consult the {@link _ManagePropertyArray() _ManagePropertyArray} method, in which the first parameter will be the constant {@link kTAG_KIND kTAG_KIND}.

The method will also set the {@link _IsDirty() dirty} {@link kFLAG_STATE_DIRTY status}.

This method can be used to manage the node {@link kTAG_TYPE type}, in general it reflects the {@link Term() term} {@link COntologyTerm::Type() type}.

The method accepts the following parameters:

  • $theValue: The value or operation:
    • NULL: Return the current value.
    • FALSE: Delete Set value exception.
  • $getOld: Determines what the method will return:
    • TRUE: Return the value before it was eventually modified.
    • FALSE: Return the value after it was eventually modified.

The method will also set the {@link _IsDirty() dirty} {@link kFLAG_STATE_DIRTY status}.

This method can be used to manage the measure data {@link kTAG_CARDINALITY type}, it uses the standard accessor {@link CAttribute::ManageOffset() method} to manage the {@link kTAG_TYPE offset}:

  • $theValue: The value or operation:
    • NULL: Return the current value.
    • FALSE: Delete the value.
    • string: String values represent the cardinality enumeration:
      • {@link kCARD_0_1 kCARD_0_1}: Zero or one, a scalar or none.
      • {@link kCARD_1 kCARD_1}: Exactly one, a required scalar.
      • {@link kCARD_ANY kCARD_ANY}: Any, this implies that we either have an array or no data.
    • integer: An integer represents the exact cardinality, in that case we assume the data is an array of at most that number of elements.
  • $getOld: Determines what the method will return:
    • TRUE: Return the value before it was eventually modified.
    • FALSE: Return the value after it was eventually modified.

This method can be used to manage the node {@link kTAG_DOMAIN domains}, in general it reflects the {@link Term() term} {@link COntologyTermObject::Domain() domains}.

For a more thorough reference of how this method works, please consult the {@link _ManagePropertyArray() _ManagePropertyArray} method, in which the first parameter will be the constant {@link kTAG_DOMAIN kTAG_DOMAIN}.

The method will also set the {@link _IsDirty() dirty} {@link kFLAG_STATE_DIRTY status}.

This method can be used to manage the node {@link kTAG_CATEGORY categories}, in general it reflects the {@link Term() term} {@link COntologyTermObject::Category() categories}.

For a more thorough reference of how this method works, please consult the {@link _ManagePropertyArray() _ManagePropertyArray} method, in which the first parameter will be the constant {@link kTAG_CATEGORY kTAG_CATEGORY}.

The method will also set the {@link _IsDirty() dirty} {@link kFLAG_STATE_DIRTY status}.

This method can be used to create a graph edge or relation between the current node and an object node using a predicate node. This method consideres the triplet subject node/predicate term/object node as the relationship identifier when considering duplicate relationships. For that reason the subject and object terms of the relationship must relate to {@link _IsCommitted() committed} nodes.

The method accepts the following parameters:

  • $theContainer: The graph and term containers as an array:
    • {@link kTAG_NODE kTAG_NODE}: This element should hold the nodes container, it must be a Everyman\Neo4j\Client instance.
    • {@link kTAG_TERM kTAG_TERM}: This element should hold the terms container, it must be a {@link CContainer CContainer} instance.
  • $thePredicate: The predicate term:
    • COntologyNode: The node {@link Term() term} {@link kTAG_GID global} {@link COntologyTerm::GID() identifier}.
    • {@link COntologyTerm COntologyTerm}: The term {@link kTAG_GID global} identifier will be used as the {@link COntologyEdge node} {@link COntologyEdge::Type() type}.
    • Everyman\Neo4j\Relationship: The relationship's type will be used as the predicate, all other elements of the provided edge node will be ignored.
    • string: Any other type will be converted to string and will be used as the {@link COntologyEdge node} {@link COntologyEdge::Type() type}.
  • $theObject: The destination node or relationship object node:
    • COntologyNode: The method will use it's {@link Node() node}.
    • Everyman\Neo4j\Node: The method will use it as the relationship object.
    • integer: The method will search for the node corresponding to the provided number, if the node was not found, the method will raise an exception.
    • other: Any other type will raise an exception.
  • $doDuplicate: This flag determines whether cuplicate relationships are allowed: if FALSE, if a relationship with the same subject and object nodes, along with the same predicate term are found, it will be considered a duplicate, and this method will actually return that relationship.

The method will return a {@link COntologyEdge COntologyEdge} object, or raise an exception if the operation was not successful.

This method will return all nodes that are related to the current one in an array of {@link COntologyEdge edge} nodes whose elements are structured as follows:

  • Key: The edge ID.
  • Value: The edge {@link COntologyEdge object}.

The method accepts the following parameters:

  • $theContainer: The graph and term containers as an array:
    • {@link kTAG_NODE kTAG_NODE}: This element should hold the nodes container, it must be a Everyman\Neo4j\Client instance.
    • {@link kTAG_TERM kTAG_TERM}: This element should hold the terms container, it must be a {@link CContainer CContainer} instance.
  • $thePredicate: The predicate terms as an array of the following types:
    • COntologyNode: The node {@link Term() term} {@link kTAG_GID global} {@link COntologyTerm::GID() identifier}.
    • {@link COntologyTerm COntologyTerm}: The term {@link kTAG_GID global} identifier will be used as the {@link COntologyEdge node} {@link COntologyEdge::Type() type}.
    • Everyman\Neo4j\Relationship: The relationship's type will be used as the predicate, all other elements of the provided edge node will be ignored.
    • string: Any other type will be converted to string and will be used as the {@link COntologyEdge node} {@link COntologyEdge::Type() type}.
  • $theDirection: The direction of the relation:
    • out: Outgoing relations, the current node is the subject.
    • in: Incoming relations, the current node is the object.
    • all: Incoming and outgoing relations (default), the current node is the object or the subject.

docblock.description: Check whether a given offset exists.
docblock.long-description: We overload this method to wrap the internal array over the node properties.

docblock.description: Return a value at a given offset.
docblock.long-description:
We overload this method to wrap the internal array over the node properties.

In this class no offset may have a NULL value, if this method returns a NULL value, it means that the offset doesn't exist.

We overload this method to wrap the internal array over the node properties.

Note that if the node exists the method will return an integer, if not, it will return NULL.

docblock.description: Create a copy of the array.
docblock.long-description:
