If you provide the {@link kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES} parameter, only those {@link COntologyEdge edges} whose type matches any of the predicate {@link COntologyTerm term} identifiers provided in that parameter will be selected.

If you omit the {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS} parameter, no elements will be returned. The service does not use {@link kAPI_DATA_PAGING paging} options.

The record {@link kAPI_AFFECTED_COUNT count} refers to the edges count.

Note that the {@link kAPI_CONTAINER container} is not required, if omitted it will be initialised to the {@link kDEFAULT_CNT_TERMS kDEFAULT_CNT_TERMS} constant.

This command can be used to search for {@link CDataset datasets} according to the parameters provided to the service:

  • {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS}: This parameter represents a list of {@link CDataset dataset} identifiers that can be expressed as:
    • string: In this case the value is interpreted as the dataset global {@link kTAG_GID identifier}.
    • array: In this case the value is interpreted as the dataset local {@link kTAG_LID identifier}.
  • {@link kAPI_DATA_QUERY kAPI_DATA_QUERY}: This parameter represents a {@link CMongoQuery query}.

The two options are not exclusive and will be applied together with an {@link kOPERATOR_AND AND} operator.

If you omit the {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS} parameter the service will enforce the use of {@link kAPI_DATA_PAGING paging} options.

The service will check the {@link kAPI_DATA_SORT kAPI_DATA_SORT} parameter to order the returned records by the list of fields provided in that parameter.

The service will also check the {@link kAPI_DATA_FIELD kAPI_DATA_FIELD} parameter to restrict the returned fields to the provided list.

In this service the {@link kAPI_CONTAINER container} is not required, if omitted it will be initialised to the {@link kDEFAULT_CNT_DATASET kDEFAULT_CNT_DATASET} constant.

If the service matches datasets, it will return an array structured as follows:

  • Key: The {@link CDataset dataset} global {@link kTAG_GID identifier}.
  • Value: The contents of the {@link CDataset dataset}.
This option refers to the user {@link CEntity::Code() code} for the {@link kAPI_OP_LOGIN login} operation.
This option refers to the user {@link CUser::Password() password} for the {@link kAPI_OP_LOGIN login} operation.

This option refers to a list of object identifiers, this option is used by assorted operations to receive the list of objects to be retrieved; the type of the list's elements is determined by the operation.

This option refers to a list of predicate {@link COntologyTerm term} identifiers, this option is used by operations involving the selection of {@link COntologyEdge edge} nodes: only those {@link COntologyEdge edge} nodes referring to any of the provided predicate {@link COntologyTerm term} identifiers will be selected.

Note that this parameter depends on the {@link kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES_INC kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES_INC} parameter: if the latter is 1, it means that only edges whose predicate is among this list will be selected; if the value is 0, only edges whose predicate is not among this list will be selected.

This option refers to the list of {@link kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES predicates}: it is a boolean (1/0) flag that determines whether the {@link kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES predicates} list is to be considered as inclusive or exclusive. If omitted it defaults to 1 (inclusion).

This option is used when retrieving {@link kAPI_OP_GET_RELS edges}: it indicates the direction of the relationships in regard to the node identifiers provided in the {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS} parameter:

  • {@link kAPI_DIRECTION_IN kAPI_DIRECTION_IN}: Incoming relationships, this will select all elements that point to the objects provided in the {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS} parameter.
  • {@link kAPI_DIRECTION_OUT kAPI_DIRECTION_OUT}: Outgoing relationships, this will select all elements pointed to by the objects provided in the {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS} parameter.
  • {@link kAPI_DIRECTION_ALL kAPI_DIRECTION_ALL}: All relationships, this will select all elements both pointing to and pointed to by the objects provided in the {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS} parameter.

This option is used when retrieving for {@link kAPI_OP_GET_RELS relationships}: it indicates the amount of levels to follow.

If the integer parameter is omitted, the service will force a one level step, if the parameter is negative, it means that the service will continue until all levels have been reached.
This tag will hold the list of terms.
This tag will hold the list of nodes.
This tag will hold the list of edges.
This tag {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_NODES refers} to the subject {@link COntologyNode node} of a relationship.
This tag {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_TERMS refers} to the predicate {@link COntologyTerm term} of a relationship.
This tag {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_NODES refers} to the object {@link COntologyNode node} of a relationship.
This tag indicates an incoming relationship, in other words, all elements that point to the current object.
This tag indicates an outgoing relationship, in other words, all elements to which the current object points to.
This tag indicates incoming and outgoing relationships, in other words, all elements that are related to the current object, both pointing to it and pointed by it.

This include file contains the user class definitions.
This include file contains the ontology term class definitions.
This include file contains the ontology data tag class definitions.
This include file contains the ontology node class definitions.
This include file contains the ontology edge class definitions.
This include file contains all local definitions to this class.

This class overloads its {@link CMongoDataWrapper ancestor} to implement a web-service customised to the germplasm data warehouse.

This class adds the following operations:

  • {@link kAPI_OP_LOGIN kAPI_OP_LOGIN}: Login, this operation expects the user {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_CODE code} and {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_PASS password} and will return the matching user.
  • {@link kAPI_OP_GET_TERMS kAPI_OP_GET_TERMS}: Get terms, this operation will return the list of ontology {@link COntologyTerm terms} matching the identifiers provided in the {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS} option. This list is expected to hold {@link COntologyTerm term} {@link kTAG_GID identifiers}.
  • {@link kAPI_OP_GET_NODES kAPI_OP_GET_NODES}: Get terms, this operation will return the list of ontology {@link COntologyTerm terms} matching the identifiers provided in the {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS} option. This list is expected to hold {@link COntologyTerm term} {@link kTAG_GID identifiers}.

The class adds the following options:

  • {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_CODE kAPI_OPT_USER_CODE}: User code, this option expects a string corresponding to the user {@link CEntity::Code() code}.
  • {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_PASS kAPI_OPT_USER_PASS}: User code, this option expects a string corresponding to the user {@link CUser::Password() password}.
  • {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS}: Identifiers list, this option expects an array of object identifiers. The actual type of these elements is determined by the operation.

This method is responsible for parsing and setting all default and provided options, derived classes should overload this method to handle custom options.

In this class we enforce {@link kAPI_DATA_PAGING paging} options if the

tag.name: link
tag.description: identifiers} list was not provided and the operation is get {@link kAPI_OP_GET_TERMS terms}.

docblock.long-description: In this class we instantiate the Neo4j client.
We overload this method to parse the user {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_CODE code} and {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_PASS password} tags.

This method should perform any needed formatting before the request will be handled.

In this class we handle the parameters to be decoded

This method should check that the request is valid and that all required parameters have been sent.

In this class we add the {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS} parameter validation.
This method will parse the user {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS identifiers} parameter.
This method will parse the {@link kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES predicates} parameter.
This method will parse the predicates {@link kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES_INC inclusion} parameter.
This method will parse the relations {@link kAPI_OPT_DIRECTION direction} parameter.
This method will parse the user {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_CODE code} parameter.
This method will parse the user {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_PASS password} parameter.
This method will parse the relations {@link kAPI_OPT_LEVELS levels} parameter.

This method will format the request query.

In this class we enforce the root selector for the {@link kAPI_OP_GET_ROOTS kAPI_OP_GET_ROOTS} service.

docblock.description: This method will format the request identifiers list.
docblock.long-description:
In this class we perform different actions depending on which operation was requested:

  • {@link kAPI_OP_GET_TERMS kAPI_OP_GET_TERMS}: Each provided identifier that is not an array will be hashed and the resulting array will be used to generate a {@link CQueryStatement::Member() member} {@link kAPI_DATA_QUERY query}.
  • {@link kAPI_OP_GET_NODES kAPI_OP_GET_NODES} and {@link kAPI_OP_GET_EDGES kAPI_OP_GET_EDGES}: The same actions as the previous case, except that the resulting query will be treated as a list of numbers.

In this class we handle the terms list {@link kAPI_OP_GET_TERMS operation} by creating a query and using the {@link kAPI_OP_GET GET} handler, in this method we create the {@link CMongoQuery query}.

docblock.description: This method will format the request predicates list.
docblock.long-description: In this class we {@link _DecodeParameter() decode} the parameter.

This method can be used to check whether the provided {@link kAPI_OPERATION operation} parameter is valid.

In this class we check that both the user {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_CODE code} and {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_PASS password} have been sent when requesting a {@link kAPI_OP_LOGIN login} operation, in addition to the {@link kAPI_DATABASE database} and {@link kAPI_CONTAINER container} references.
We overload this method for handling the {@link kAPI_OP_MATCH_TERMS kAPI_OP_MATCH_TERMS} service.

We implement this method to check if all the provided identifiers correspond to existing records, if this is not the case, the method will throw an exception.

This operation will only be performed for the {@link kAPI_OP_SET_TAGS kAPI_OP_SET_TAGS} operation.
This method will handle the request.

This method will first {@link CUser::__construct() load} the user by using its {@link CEntity::Code() code}, then match the {@link CUser::Password() password}; if they match it will return the user record.

This method will handle all requests that result in a query returning a single list of selected records, it is equivalent to the {@link _Handle_Get() _Handle_Get} method, with the only difference being that each found element is here indexed by the object global {@link kTAG_GID identifier}.
This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_GET kAPI_OP_GET} request, which corresponds to the find Mongo query.

This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_SET_TAGS kAPI_OP_SET_TAGS} request, which expects a list of {@link COntologyTerm term} and {@link COntologyEdge edge} identifiers in the {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS} parameter, each of those elements will either be a {@link CDataTypeBinary binary} object or an array of {@link COntologyEdge edge} identifiers.

This method will match/create data {@link COntologyTag tags} and return the list.

This method will process the query provided in the {@link kAPI_DATA_QUERY kAPI_DATA_QUERY} parameter and return a result structured as follows:

  • {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_NODES kAPI_RESPONSE_NODES}: The list of found nodes as follows:
    • Key: The node ID.
    • Value: The node properties.
  • {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_TERMS kAPI_RESPONSE_TERMS}: The list of terms related to the list of found nodes as follows:
    • Key: The {@link COntologyTerm term} global {@link kTAG_GID identifier}.
    • Value: The contents of the {@link COntologyTerm term}.

This method will process the query provided in the {@link kAPI_DATA_QUERY kAPI_DATA_QUERY} parameter and return a result structured as follows:

  • {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_EDGES kAPI_RESPONSE_EDGES}: The list of edges as an array structured as follows:
    • key: The edge identifier.
    • Value: An array structured as follows:
      • {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_SUBJECT kAPI_RESPONSE_SUBJECT}: The subject {@link COntologyNode node} ID.
      • {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_PREDICATE kAPI_RESPONSE_PREDICATE}: The predicate {@link COntologyTerm term} {@link kTAG_GID identifier}.
      • {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_OBJECT kAPI_RESPONSE_OBJECT}: The object {@link COntologyNode node} ID.
  • {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_NODES kAPI_RESPONSE_NODES}: The list of {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_SUBJECT subject} and {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_OBJECT object} found nodes as follows:
    • Key: The node ID.
    • Value: The node properties.
  • {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_TERMS kAPI_RESPONSE_TERMS}: The list of terms related to the list of found nodes and to the edge predicate as follows:
    • Key: The {@link COntologyTerm term} global {@link kTAG_GID identifier}.
    • Value: The contents of the {@link COntologyTerm term}.

This method will return the same structure as the {@link kAPI_OP_GET_EDGES kAPI_OP_GET_EDGES} service:

  • {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_EDGES kAPI_RESPONSE_EDGES}: The list of edges as an array structured as follows:
    • key: The edge identifier.
    • Value: An array structured as follows:
      • {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_SUBJECT kAPI_RESPONSE_SUBJECT}: The subject {@link COntologyNode node} ID.
      • {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_PREDICATE kAPI_RESPONSE_PREDICATE}: The predicate {@link COntologyTerm term} {@link kTAG_GID identifier}.
      • {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_OBJECT kAPI_RESPONSE_OBJECT}: The object {@link COntologyNode node} ID.
  • {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_NODES kAPI_RESPONSE_NODES}: The list of {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_SUBJECT subject} and {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_OBJECT object} found nodes as follows:
    • Key: The node ID.
    • Value: The node properties.
  • {@link kAPI_RESPONSE_TERMS kAPI_RESPONSE_TERMS}: The list of terms related to the list of found nodes and to the edge predicate as follows:
    • Key: The {@link COntologyTerm term} global {@link kTAG_GID identifier}.
    • Value: The contents of the {@link COntologyTerm term}.

Depending on the value of the {@link kAPI_OPT_DIRECTION kAPI_OPT_DIRECTION} parameter:

  • {@link kAPI_DIRECTION_IN kAPI_DIRECTION_IN}: The service will return all {@link COntologyEdge edges} that point to the {@link COntologyNode nodes} provided in the {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS} parameter.
  • {@link kAPI_DIRECTION_OUT kAPI_DIRECTION_OUT}: The service will return all {@link COntologyEdge edges} pointing from the {@link COntologyNode nodes} provided in the {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS} parameter.
  • {@link kAPI_DIRECTION_ALL kAPI_DIRECTION_ALL}: The service will return all {@link COntologyEdge edges} connected in any way to the {@link COntologyNode nodes} provided in the {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS} parameter.

The service also expects a {@link kAPI_OPT_LEVELS kAPI_OPT_LEVELS}parameter, a signed integer, that indicates how many levels to recurse the graph traversal, if this parameter is not provided, it will default to 1 level; to traverse all levels this parameter should be set to a negative number; a level of 0 will only return the list of involved nodes and terms.

If the {@link kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES} parameter was provided, only those {@link COntologyEdge edges} whose type matches any of the predicate {@link COntologyTerm term} identifiers provided in that parameter will be selected.

If the {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS} parameter was not provided, the method will return the above structure with no content.

Note: this method handles the case in which the {@link kAPI_OPT_DIRECTION direction} is not provided: in that case it will treat the list of {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS identifiers} as a list of edge node IDs and will work as the {@link kAPI_OP_GET_EDGES kAPI_OP_GET_EDGES} service.
This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_HELP kAPI_OP_HELP} request, which should return the list of supported operations.
This method will escape the provided element to make it compatible with the Lucene query language, the method expects the provided parameter to be an element excluding specific lucene operators.

This method will traverse the graph in the direction set in the {@link kAPI_OPT_DIRECTION kAPI_OPT_DIRECTION} parameter and {@link _EdgeParser() collect} all found edge elements in the provided parameters.

The parameters to this method are:

  • &$theList: List of current level node identifiers.
  • &$theTerms: Reference to the list of term identifiers.
  • &$theNodes: Reference to the list of nodes.
  • &$theEdges: Reference to the list of edge elements.
  • &$thePredicates: Reference to the list of predicates to be considered.
  • $theLevel: Current traversal depth level, 0 means the lowest.

The method will return the number of processed elements count.

This method will collect the provided edge elements and set them into the provided parameters.

The parameters to this method are:

  • $theEdge: Edge node to handle.
  • &$theTerms: Reference to the list of term identifiers.
  • &$theNodes: Reference to the list of nodes.
  • &$theEdges: Reference to the list of edge elements.

The method will return 1 if the edge was handled, 0 if not.
This include file contains the parent class definitions.
This include file contains all definitions of the server object.

This class represents a germplasm warehouse web-services data wrapper client, it facilitates the job of requesting information from servers derived from the {@link CWarehouseWrapper CWarehouseWrapper} class.

This class adds the following properties to its {@link CWrapperClient ancestor}:

  • User {@link UserCode() code}: This {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_CODE property} represents the user code provided to the {@link kAPI_OP_LOGIN login} operation.
  • User {@link UserPass() password}: This {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_PASS property} represents the user password provided to the {@link kAPI_OP_LOGIN login} operation.

The class also adds the following new operations:

  • {@link kAPI_OP_LOGIN kAPI_OP_LOGIN}: This is the tag that represents the login operation, it will return the matching user {@link CUser object} if the provided user {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_CODE code} and {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_PASS password} match.

We {@link CDataWrapperClient::Operation() overload} this method to add the following allowed operations:

  • {@link kAPI_OP_LOGIN kAPI_OP_LOGIN}: This is the tag that represents the user login operation, it will return the {@link CUser user} matching the provided user {@link UserCode() code} and {@link UserPass() password}.

This method can be used to manage the object {@link kAPI_OPT_ID ID}, it accepts a value which represents either the object identifier, or the requested operation:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method can be used to manage the object {@link kAPI_OPT_TITLE title}, it accepts a value which represents either the object title, or the requested operation:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method can be used to manage the user {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_CODE code}, it accepts a string which represents either the user code, or the requested operation:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method can be used to manage the user {@link kAPI_OPT_USER_PASS password}, it accepts a string which represents either the user password, or the requested operation:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method can be used to manage the {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS identifiers}, it uses the standard accessor {@link CAttribute::ManageArrayOffset() method} to manage the list of identifiers.

For a more thorough reference of how this method works, please consult the {@link CAttribute::ManageArrayOffset() CAttribute::ManageArrayOffset} method, in which the second parameter will be the constant {@link kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS kAPI_OPT_IDENTIFIERS}.

This method can be used to manage the {@link kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES predicates}, it uses the standard accessor {@link CAttribute::ManageArrayOffset() method} to manage the list of predicates.

For a more thorough reference of how this method works, please consult the {@link CAttribute::ManageArrayOffset() CAttribute::ManageArrayOffset} method, in which the second parameter will be the constant {@link kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES}.

This method can be used to manage the predicates {@link kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES_INC selector}, it uses the standard accessor {@link CAttribute::ManageArrayOffset() method} to manage the predicates selector.

Note that the only values that can be set are 1 or 0, boolean values are not supported, this method will also handle Y/N y/n and string 1/0 values.

For a more thorough reference of how this method works, please consult the {@link CAttribute::ManageArrayOffset() CAttribute::ManageArrayOffset} method, in which the second parameter will be the constant {@link kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES kAPI_OPT_PREDICATES}.

This method can be used to manage the {@link kAPI_OP_GET_RELS edges} direction, it accepts a string which represents either the relationship {@link kAPI_OPT_DIRECTION direction}, or the requested operation:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter:
    • {@link kAPI_DIRECTION_IN kAPI_DIRECTION_IN}: Incoming relationships.
    • {@link kAPI_DIRECTION_OUT kAPI_DIRECTION_OUT}: Outgoing relationships.
    • {@link kAPI_DIRECTION_ALL kAPI_DIRECTION_ALL}: Both incoming and outgoing relationships.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method can be used to manage the {@link kAPI_OPT_LEVELS levels} of depth in graph {@link kAPI_OP_GET_RELS traversals}, it accepts an integer which represents the number of levels to traverse; if the value is negative, all levels will be traversed.

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.
This is the tag that represents the HELP web-service operation, which returns the list of supported operations and options.
This is the tag that represents the PING web-service operation, which returns a status response.

This is the tag that represents the web-service request and response format.

This applies both to the request and the response; if the parameter is not provided we assume the {@link kTYPE_JSON JSON} format.

Cardinality: one.

This is the tag that represents the web-service operation.

Cardinality: one.

If the value of this tag resolves to TRUE, the request will be logged in the response.

Cardinality: one or zero.

If the value of this tag resolves to TRUE, eventual errors will bare the trace.

Cardinality: one or zero.

This is the tag that represents the request time stamp, it should contain the timestamp in which the client sent the request; if present, the service will return the following time stamps:

  • {@link kAPI_REC_STAMP kAPI_REC_STAMP}: Received time stamp.
  • {@link kAPI_PARSE_STAMP kAPI_PARSE_STAMP}: Parsed time stamp.
  • {@link kAPI_RES_STAMP kAPI_RES_STAMP}: Response time stamp.

These values are provided as floating point numbers such as the result of the gettimeofday( true ) function.

Cardinality: one or zero.

This is the tag that represents the time stamp in which the request was received.

These values are provided as floating point numbers such as the result of the gettimeofday( true ) function.

These values are provided as floating point numbers such as the result of the gettimeofday( true ) function.

Cardinality: one or zero.

This is the tag that represents the time stamp in which the response was sent.

These values are provided as floating point numbers such as the result of the gettimeofday( true ) function.

Cardinality: one or zero.

This class represents a web-services wrapper server, it is the ancestor of web-service classes in this library.

Wrappers are objects that respond to standard web calls and receive parameters in both GET and POST parameters, the main two parameters handled by this class are:

  • {@link kAPI_FORMAT kAPI_FORMAT} (required): The data format of the response, it will be returned as:
    • {@link kTYPE_PHP kTYPE_PHP}: A PHP-serialised string.
    • {@link kTYPE_JSON kTYPE_JSON}: A JSON-serialised string.
  • {@link kAPI_OPERATION kAPI_OPERATION} (required): The requested operation, each class will implement specialised handlers, this class only implements the following two operations:
    • {@link kAPI_OP_HELP kAPI_OP_HELP}: A LIST-OP command, this command will return in the {@link kAPI_DATA_RESPONSE response} section the list of supported operations as an array structured as follows:
      • index: The index will be the operation code.
      • value: The value will be the operation description.
    • {@link kAPI_OP_PING kAPI_OP_PING}: A PING command, this can be used to check if a service is alive.

If both the above parameters are present, the service will return an array constituted by the following three sections:

  • {@link kAPI_DATA_STATUS kAPI_DATA_STATUS}: Operation status. This section is returned by default and will inform on the status of the requested operation. It consists of an array containing the following elements:
    • {@link kTAG_STATUS kTAG_STATUS}: Response status. This element will be returned by default regardless of the operation outcome. This corresponds to the severity of the response and it can take the following values:
      • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_IDLE kMESSAGE_TYPE_IDLE}: This is the status of the web-service before any operation has been executed, or when the operation was successful; this is the response of a successful {@link kAPI_OP_PING ping} request.
      • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_NOTICE kMESSAGE_TYPE_NOTICE}: The operation was successful and a notice message was returned.
      • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_MESSAGE kMESSAGE_TYPE_MESSAGE}: The operation was successful and a message was returned.
      • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_WARNING kMESSAGE_TYPE_WARNING}: The operation was successful but a warning was raised.
      • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_ERROR kMESSAGE_TYPE_ERROR}: The operation failed because of an error.
      • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_FATAL kMESSAGE_TYPE_FATAL}: The operation failed because of a fatal error, this will generally mean that the web-service is not operational.
      • {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_BUG kMESSAGE_TYPE_BUG}: The operation failed because of a bug, the developers should be informed of this kind of errors.
    • {@link kTAG_CODE kTAG_CODE}: Status code. This element will be returned by default regardless of the operation outcome. It corresponds to the error code; {@link kERROR_OK zero} means no error.
    • {@link kTAG_DESCRIPTION kTAG_DESCRIPTION}: Status message. The response message from the operation, this element is used to return informative messages or to return error messages when the service fails. It will generally be formatted as an array structured as follows:
      • {@link kTAG_TYPE kTAG_TYPE}: The data type of the message, it will be a {@link kTYPE_STRING string} in general.
      • {@link kTAG_LANGUAGE kTAG_LANGUAGE}: The language ISO 639 2 character code in which the message is expressed in.
      • {@link kTAG_DATA kTAG_DATA}: The actual message data contents.
    • {@link kAPI_AFFECTED_COUNT kAPI_AFFECTED_COUNT}: Record count. The total number of elements affected by the operation. This tag will only be used by derived classes returning data elements.
    • {@link kTAG_ANNOTATION kTAG_ANNOTATION}: Attachments. A list of key/value pairs containing information relevant to the operation response. For instance, if a series of parameters are required and were not provided, this could list them.
  • {@link kAPI_DATA_REQUEST kAPI_DATA_REQUEST}: Service request. This section will return the actual request provided to the service, this can be used for debugging purposes and will only occur if the optional {@link kAPI_OPT_LOG_REQUEST kAPI_OPT_LOG_REQUEST} parameter has been set to 1.
  • {@link kAPI_DATA_TIMING kAPI_DATA_TIMING}: Timers. This section holds timing information, it will be returned only if you provide the time of day [gettimeofday( TRUE )] in the {@link kAPI_REQ_STAMP kAPI_REQ_STAMP} parameter. This section is structured as follows:
    • {@link kAPI_REQ_STAMP kAPI_REQ_STAMP}: Request time stamp, the time in which the request was sent; this is the same value sent by the caller in the {@link kAPI_REQ_STAMP kAPI_REQ_STAMP} parameter.
    • {@link kAPI_PARSE_STAMP kAPI_PARSE_STAMP}: Parse time stamp, the time in which the service finished parsing the request.
    • {@link kAPI_RES_STAMP kAPI_RES_STAMP}: Response time stamp, the time in which the response was sent.
  • {@link kAPI_DATA_RESPONSE kAPI_DATA_RESPONSE}: Response, this section will hold the operation response, in this class we only respond to {@link kAPI_OP_HELP operations} list requests.

Besides the {@link kAPI_FORMAT format} and {@link kAPI_OPERATION operation} parameters described in the first section, we have three other optional parameters that can be used to receive specific information sections in the response:

  • {@link kAPI_OPT_LOG_REQUEST kAPI_OPT_LOG_REQUEST}: Log the request, if the value of this parameter is 1, the response will contain the received request in the {@link kAPI_DATA_REQUEST request} section.
  • {@link kAPI_OPT_LOG_TRACE kAPI_OPT_LOG_TRACE}: Trace exceptions, if the value of this parameter is 1, in the case of an error that triggered an exception, the error response will also include the call trace.
  • {@link kAPI_REQ_STAMP kAPI_REQ_STAMP}: This parameter should hold the timestamp [gettimeofday( TRUE )] in which the client has sent the request, if provided, the service will return the timing information in the {@link kAPI_DATA_TIMING timing} section.

The parameters are expected either in GET or POST.

If either the {@link kAPI_FORMAT format} or the {@link kAPI_OPERATION operation} parameters are omitted from the request, the service will return an empty response; this is to prevent unnecessary traffic.

Instances of this class can be considered server objects, and can be implemented with this simple code snippet:

$server = new CWrapper();
$server->HandleRequest();

An example of this class implementation can be found in the {@link Wrapper.php Wrapper.php} source file.
This data member holds the request reception time stamp.

The constructor will set-up the environment and parse the request. The workflow is as follows:

  • Check required elements: The method will check if all required elements of the request are there, if that is not the case it will just exit.
  • Init {@link _InitStatus() status}: The response status will be initialised to the {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_IDLE idle} state.
  • Init {@link _InitOptions() options}: Service options will be initialised.
  • Init {@link _InitResources() resources}: Eventual resources are initialised.
  • {@link _ParseRequest() Parse} request: The request is parsed.
  • {@link _FormatRequest() Format} request: The request is normalised if necessary.
  • {@link _ValidateRequest() Validate} request: The request is validated.

This protected interface should be overloaded by derived classes to implement custom services.
This method will handle the request.

This method is responsible for initialising the {@link kAPI_DATA_STATUS status} section, derived classes may overload this method if they need to handle other states.

In this class we set the status to {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_IDLE idle} and reset the status {@link kTAG_CODE code}.

This method is responsible for parsing and setting all default and provided options, derived classes should overload this method to handle custom options.

In this class we initialise the {@link kAPI_DATA_REQUEST request} and {@link kAPI_DATA_TIMING timer} sections if required.
In derived classes this should be the method that initialises the data store resources, in this class we have no resources.

This method should be used to parse the request, check the request elements and make any necessary adjustments before the request is {@link _ValidateRequest() validated}.

This is also where the relevant request elements will be logged to the relative response sections.

The method is called by the {@link __construct() constructor} and should be overloaded to handle derived classes custom elements.

In this class we handle the {@link kAPI_FORMAT format}, {@link kAPI_OPERATION operation} and {@link kAPI_DATA_TIMING timing} elements.

This method should perform any needed formatting before the request will be handled.

In this class we do nothing.

This method should check that the request is valid and that all required parameters have been sent.

In this class we check the {@link kAPI_FORMAT format} and {@link kAPI_OPERATION operation} codes (their presence is checked by the {@link __construct() constructor}.
This method will parse the request format.
This method will parse the request operation.
This method will parse the request timers.
This method can be used to check whether the provided {@link kAPI_FORMAT format} parameter is valid.
This method can be used to check whether the provided {@link kAPI_OPERATION operation} parameter is valid.
This method will handle the request.
This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_HELP kAPI_OP_HELP} request, which should return the list of supported operations.

This method will handle the {@link kAPI_OP_PING kAPI_OP_PING} request, which can be used to check if a service is alive.

The ping request will return by default the {@link kAPI_DATA_STATUS status} block.

This method can be used to manage elements within offsets, in other words, it can be used to manage elements within an offset:

  • $theBlock: The main offset.
  • $theElement: The offset within the main offset.
  • $theValue: The new value or the operation:
    • NULL: Retrieve the element in the block.
    • FALSE: Delete the element from the block.
    • other: All other data types are interpreted as a new element.

This method can be used to set the service status according to an exception:

  • {@link CException::Severity() Severity}: This value will be set as the status {@link kTAG_STATUS status}.
  • {@link Exception::getCode() Code}: This value will be set as the status {@link kTAG_CODE code}.
  • {@link Exception::getMessage() Message}: This value will be set in the status {@link kTAG_DESCRIPTION description} field as a language block.
  • {@link Exception::getFile() File}: This value will be set in the status {@link kTAG_ANNOTATION annotations}.
  • {@link Exception::getLine() Line}: This value will be set in the status {@link kTAG_ANNOTATION annotations}.
  • {@link Exception::getTrace() Trace}: This value will be set in the status {@link kTAG_ANNOTATION annotations}.
  • {@link CException::Reference() References}: These valuew will be set in the status {@link kTAG_ANNOTATION annotations}.
This method will return the encoded response string.
This include file contains all definitions of the server object.

This class represents a web-services wrapper client, it facilitates the job of requesting information from servers derived from the {@link CWrapper CWrapper} class.

This class supports the following properties:

  • {@link Url() URL}: This element represents the web-service URL, and it is stored in the {@link kOFFSET_URL kOFFSET_URL} offset.
  • {@link Operation() Operation}: This element represents the web-service requested operation, it is stored in the {@link kAPI_OPERATION kAPI_OPERATION} offset.
  • {@link Format() Format}: This element represents the web-service parameters and response format, it is stored in the {@link kAPI_FORMAT kAPI_FORMAT} offset.
  • {@link Stamp() Stamp}: This element represents a switch to turn on and off timing information from the web service, it is stored in the {@link kAPI_REQ_STAMP kAPI_REQ_STAMP} offset.
  • Log {@link LogRequest() request}: This element represents a switch to turn on and off logging the request: if on, the request will be returned by the web-service, it is stored in the {@link kAPI_OPT_LOG_REQUEST kAPI_OPT_LOG_REQUEST} offset.
  • Log {@link LogTrace() trace}: This element represents a switch to turn on and off tracing exceptions: if on, any exception will also hold a trace, it is stored in the {@link kAPI_OPT_LOG_TRACE kAPI_OPT_LOG_TRACE} offset.

Objects of this class require at least the {@link Url() URL} {@link kOFFSET_URL offset}, {@link Operation() operation} {@link kAPI_OPERATION offset} and the {@link Format() format} {@link kAPI_FORMAT offset} to be set if they expect to have an {@link _IsInited() initialised} {@link kFLAG_STATE_INITED status}, which is necessary to send {@link Request() requests} to web-services.

The constructor will initialise the object depending on the provided parameter:

  • NULL: An empty object.
  • array: The array elements will become the object properties.
  • string: Any other value will be converted to string and will represent the web-service URL.

This method can be used to manage the {@link kOFFSET_URL URL}, it accepts a parameter which represents either the URL or the requested operation, depending on its value:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method can be used to manage the {@link kAPI_OPERATION operation}, it accepts a parameter which represents either the web-service operation code or this method operation, depending on its value:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method will check whether the provided operation is supported, if this is not the case, it will raise an exception. Derived classes should first check their specific operations, if not matched, they should pass the parameter to the parent method. In this class we support the following operations:

  • {@link kAPI_OP_HELP kAPI_OP_HELP}: HELP web-service operation, which returns the list of supported operations and options.
  • {@link kAPI_OP_PING kAPI_OP_PING}: PING web-service operation, which returns a status response.

This method can be used to manage the {@link kAPI_FORMAT format} in which both the parameters are sent and the response is returned from the web-service. It accepts a parameter which represents either the web-service format code or this method operation, depending on its value:

  • NULL: Return the current value.
  • FALSE: Delete the current value.
  • other: Set the value with the provided parameter.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method will check whether the provided format is supported, if this is not the case, it will raise an exception. Derived classes should first check their specific operations, if not matched, they should pass the parameter to the parent method. In this class we support the following operations:

  • {@link kTYPE_PHP kTYPE_PHP}: Parameters and response will be serialized.
  • {@link kTYPE_XML kTYPE_XML}: Parameters and response will be encoded in XML.
  • {@link kTYPE_JSON kTYPE_JSON}: Parameters and response will be encoded in JSON.
  • {@link kTYPE_META kTYPE_META}: This data type can be used to return service metadata, the {@link Execute() request} will return headers metadata for troubleshooting, rather than the response from the web-service.

This method can be used to turn on or off the time-stamp section in the web-service response, the method accepts a single parameter that if resolves to TRUE it will turn on this option, if not it will turn it off.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method can be used to turn on or off the request section in the web-service response, the method accepts a single parameter that if resolves to TRUE it will turn on this option, if not it will turn it off.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

This method can be used to turn on or off the trace in the event an exception is raised, the method accepts a single parameter that if resolves to TRUE it will turn on this option, if not it will turn it off.

The second parameter is a boolean which if TRUE will return the old value when replacing values; if FALSE, it will return the currently set value.

docblock.description: Set a value for a given offset.
docblock.long-description: We overload this method to manage the {@link _IsInited() inited} {@link kFLAG_STATE_INITED status}: this is set if {@link kOFFSET_URL URL}, {@link kAPI_OPERATION operation} and {@link kAPI_FORMAT format} are all set.

docblock.description: Reset a value for a given offset.
docblock.long-description: We overload this method to manage the {@link _IsInited() inited} {@link kFLAG_STATE_INITED status}: this is set if {@link kOFFSET_URL URL}, {@link kAPI_OPERATION operation} and {@link kAPI_FORMAT format} are all set.
This method can be used to sent an HTTP request using the current contents of the object and return a response.

This method can be used to sent an HTTP request via GET or POST.

The method accepts the following parameters:

  • $theUrl: The request URL.
  • $theParams: An array of key/value parameters for the request.
  • $theMode: The request mode:
    • GET: GET, default.
    • POST: POST.
  • $theFormat: The request format:
    • {@link kTYPE_XML kTYPE_XML}: XML.
    • {@link kTYPE_PHP kTYPE_PHP}: PHP.
    • {@link kTYPE_JSON kTYPE_JSON}: JSON.
    • {@link kTYPE_META kTYPE_META}: Metadata: if you provide this format, the method will return the metadata of the operation for troubleshooting purposes.
This code indicates successful operation or idle state.
This error indicates that the current state is invalid or not fit in order to perform the requested information.
This error indicates that an invalid parameter was passed to a method or function.
This error indicates that a parameter to a method is missing a required option.
This error indicates a call to a non existing method. In general this will happen when mapping functions to the class and the called function does not exist.
This error indicates the attempt to operate with an object that has not yet been properly initialised.
This error indicates the attempt to either perform an unsupported operation, or that an unsupported data type was provided to a method.
This error indicates the attempt to modify a protected attribute, this usually occurs when modifying a significative offset of an object that uses it as an identifier.
This error is raised when an expected object is missing from a container.

This error is raised when a duplicate element is found in a collection which is supposed to have unique elements.

In general this is the error that will be raised when {@link kFLAG_PERSIST_INSERT inserting} a duplicate element in a container.

This error is raised when the requested operation is not yet implemented. This is an indication that there is the intention of implementing the requested feature, but that this was not yet done.

This error is raised by operations rather than by data; in the latter case you would most likely get an {@link kERROR_UNSUPPORTED unsupported} error.

This bitfield value indicates that the object has been initialised, this means that all required data members are present. In general, this means that elements comprising the object's {@link CObject::_Index() index} are not missing.

If this flag is not set, it means that the object lacks required elements, thus it will not work correctly, or it cannot be stored persistently.

This bitfield value indicates that the object has been modified. In general this state is only triggered by modifications to persistent data members; run time members should not be included. Methods that serialise or modify the contents of the object should respectively reset and set this flag.

If the flag is not set, this means that the object has not been modified;

This bitfield value indicates that the object has been either loaded from a persistent container, or that it has been saved to a persistent container. If used in combination with the {@link kFLAG_STATE_DIRTY dirty} flag, it allows committing the object only if it was modified.

If the flag is off, this means that the object was not instantiated from a persistent container, or that it was not committed to it.

This bitfield value indicates an encoded state. This status is usually associated to {@link CPersistentObject persistent} objects: if the state is ON it means that all elements having custom data types, or data formats unsuitable for being transmitted over the network, will be converted to standard data {@link CDataType types}. This flag will be used by {@link CContainer containers} to determine whether to perform conversions before and after persisting the objects.
This value masks all the state flags.
This bitfield value indicates that we intend to insert an object in a container, this means that if a duplicate object already exists, the operation should fail.

This bitfield value indicates that we intend to update an object in a container, this means that the object must exist, or the operation must fail. This operation assumes that the provided object will replace the entire contents of the existing one.

This bitfield value indicates that we intend to modify an existing object, the difference with the {@link kFLAG_PERSIST_UPDATE update} operation is that while the latter will replace the whole object, in this case only the matching object attributes will be updated and the unmatched ones will be left untouched. This option applies when adding or modifying a subset of an object.

This bitfield value indicates that we intend to either {@link kFLAG_PERSIST_INSERT insert} an object, if it doesn't already exist, or {@link kFLAG_PERSIST_UPDATE update} an existing object. In the latter case, this operation assumes that the provided object will replace the entire contents of the existing one.
This bitfield value indicates that we intend to delete an object from a container, if the object doesn't exist, the operation should still succeed.
This value masks the access flags that imply writing to the collection, with the exception of {@link kFLAG_PERSIST_DELETE deleting}.
This value masks all the persistence action flags.

This bitfield value indicates that we intend to increment a value of a field, if the field does not exist, the provided increment value will be set in the field. This option must be provided in conjunction with the {kFLAG_PERSIST_MODIFY kFLAG_PERSIST_MODIFY} flag.

This bitfield value indicates that we intend to append a value to an existing field, if field is not present, an array with the provided value will be set in the field; if the field does not contain an array, an error should occur. This option must be provided in conjunction with the {kFLAG_PERSIST_MODIFY kFLAG_PERSIST_MODIFY} flag.

This bitfield value indicates that we intend to add a value to an existing array field only if this value is not yet present, the options are the same as for the {@link kFLAG_MODIFY_APPEND kFLAG_MODIFY_APPEND} flag.

This bitfield value indicates that we intend to remove the last or first element of an array: if the value is 1 the last element will be removed, if the value is -1 it will be the first element. This option must be provided in conjunction with the {kFLAG_PERSIST_MODIFY kFLAG_PERSIST_MODIFY} flag.

This bitfield value indicates that we intend to remove all occurrences of a value from an array. If the field exists, but it is not an array, an error should be raised. This option must be provided in conjunction with the {kFLAG_PERSIST_MODIFY kFLAG_PERSIST_MODIFY} flag.
This value masks the access flags that indicate modification options to the {@link kFLAG_PERSIST_MODIFY kFLAG_PERSIST_MODIFY} persistence action.

This bitfield value indicates that we intend to include {@link kTAG_REFERENCE_ID identifier} information to the reference, this is used when {@link CContainer::Reference() converting} a {@link CPersistentObject persistent} object to a reference.

This bitfield value indicates that we intend to include {@link kTAG_REFERENCE_CONTAINER container} information to the reference, this is used when {@link CContainer::Reference() converting} a {@link CPersistentObject persistent} object to a reference.

This bitfield value indicates that we intend to include {@link kTAG_REFERENCE_DATABASE database} information to the reference, this is used when {@link CContainer::Reference() converting} a {@link CPersistentObject persistent} object to a reference.

This bitfield value indicates that we intend to include {@link kTAG_CLASS class} information to the reference, this is used when {@link CContainer::Reference() converting} a {@link CPersistentObject persistent} object to a reference.
This value masks all the reference option flags.
If the flag is set, the string will be converted to the UTF8 character set.

If the flag is set the string will be left trimmed.

This modification will be applied after the eventual {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8 UTF-8} conversion.

If the flag is set the string will be right trimmed.

This modification will be applied after the eventual {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8 UTF-8} conversion.

If the flag is set the string will be trimmed, both left and right; this option implies that {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_LTRIM kFLAG_MODIFIER_LTRIM} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_RTRIM kFLAG_MODIFIER_RTRIM} is also set.

This modification will be applied after the eventual {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8 UTF-8} conversion.

If the flag is set and the string is empty, it will be converted to a NULL value.

This modification will be applied after the eventual {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8 UTF-8} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_TRIM trim} conversions.

If the flag is set and the string is empty, it will be converted to a 'NULL' string; this option implies that {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULL kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULL} option is also set.

This modification will be applied after the eventual {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8 UTF-8} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_TRIM trim} conversions.

If the flag is set, the string will be set to lowercase, the default case insensitive modifier. Note that depending on the {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8 UTF-8} flag, either the {@link strtolower() standard} or {@link mb_convert_case() multibyte} function will be used.

This modification will be applied after the eventual {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8 UTF-8}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_TRIM trim} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULL NULL} conversions.

If the flag is set, the string will be URL-encoded; this option and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HTML kFLAG_MODIFIER_HTML} are mutually exclusive.

This modification will be applied after the eventual {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8 UTF-8}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_TRIM trim}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULL NULL} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NOCASE lowercase} conversions.

If the flag is set, the string will be URL-encoded; this option and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_URL kFLAG_MODIFIER_URL} are mutually exclusive.

This modification will be applied after the eventual {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8 UTF-8}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_TRIM trim}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULL NULL} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NOCASE lowercase} conversions.

If the flag is set the string will be converted to a hexadecimal string; this option is mutually exclusive with the {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HASH kFLAG_MODIFIER_HASH} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HASH_BIN kFLAG_MODIFIER_HASH_BIN} flags.

This modification will be applied after the eventual {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8 UTF-8}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_TRIM trim}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULL NULL}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NOCASE lowercase} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_URL url} or {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HTML HTML} conversions.

If the flag is set the string will be converted to a hexadecimal string suitable to be used in an expression (0x00...). Note that if this flag is set it is assumed that {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEX kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEX} is also set and this flag is mutually exclusive with the {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HASH kFLAG_MODIFIER_HASH} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HASH_BIN kFLAG_MODIFIER_HASH_BIN} flags.

This modification will be applied after the eventual {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8 UTF-8}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_TRIM trim}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULL NULL}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NOCASE lowercase} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_URL url} or {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HTML HTML} conversions.

If the flag is set, the string will be hashed into a 32 character hex string; this option is mutually exclusive with the {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEX kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEX} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEXEXP kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEXEXP} flags.

This modification will be applied after the eventual {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8 UTF-8}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_TRIM trim}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULL NULL}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NOCASE lowercase} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_URL url} or {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HTML HTML} conversions.

If the flag is set, the string will be hashed and the resulting string will be a 16 character binary string. Note that if this flag is set it is assumed that {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HASH kFLAG_MODIFIER_HASH} is also set and this option is mutually exclusive with the {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEX kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEX} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEXEXP kFLAG_MODIFIER_HEXEXP} flags.

This modification will be applied after the eventual {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_UTF8 UTF-8}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_TRIM trim}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NULL NULL}, {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_NOCASE lowercase} and {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_URL url} or {@link kFLAG_MODIFIER_HTML HTML} conversions.
This value masks both trim flags.
This value masks both the NULL flags.
This value masks both the HEX flags.
This value masks the both hash flags.
This value masks the string modifier flags.
This bitfield value represents the default flags state.
This bitfield value represents the default flags mask.

This code indicates no errors.

This state can be equated to an idle state.

This code indicates a notice.

A notice is an informative message that does not imply an error, nor a situation that should be handled; it can be considered as statistical data.

This code indicates a message.

A message is an informative message that is addressed to somebody, although it does not imply an error or warning, it was issued to a receiving party.

This code indicates a warning.

Warnings are informative data that indicate a potential problem, although they do not imply an error, they indicate a potential problem or an issue that should be addressed at least at a later stage.

This code indicates an error.

Errors indicate that something prevented an operation from being performed, this does not necessarily mean that the whole process is halted, but that the results of an operation will not be as expected.

This code indicates a fatal error.

Fatal errors are {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_ERROR errors} that result in stopping the whole process: in this case the error will prevent other operations from being performed and the whole process should be halted.

This code indicates a bug.

Bugs, as opposed to {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_ERROR errors}, result from internal causes independant from external factors. A bug indicates that an operation will never execute as stated, it does not necessarily mean that it is {@link kMESSAGE_TYPE_FATAL fatal}, but rather that the behaviour of an operation does not correspond to its declaration.

This is the tag that represents the object's local unique identifier, this offset should hold a scalar value which uniquely identifies the object within the collection that holds it.

This should not be confused with the {@link kTAG_GID global} identifier, which represents the value or values used by the public to refer to that object.

This value should be tightly integrated with the database.

This is the tag that represents the object's global unique identifier, this offset should uniquely identify the object among all collections, it represents a string that may only reference that specific object.

This should not be confused with the {@link kTAG_LID local} identifier, which represents the key to the object within the local database.

This is the tag that represents the object's unique identifier, this offset is used when the {@link kTAG_LID local} identifier is not the actual value that determines the object unique key. This offset should generally be a unique index.

This is the offset used to indicate a synonym, a synonym is a string that can be used as a substitute to the term, it may be of several kinds: {@link kTYPE_EXACT exact}, {@link kTYPE_BROAD broad}, {@link kTYPE_NARROW narrow} and {@link kTYPE_RELATED related}.

docblock.description: This is the offset used to indicate a cross-reference, a cross-reference is a reference to another term in the same container, a sort of synonym, except that it is not a string, but a reference to another term object. Cross-references can be of several kinds: {@link kTYPE_EXACT exact}, {@link kTYPE_BROAD broad}, {@link kTYPE_NARROW narrow} and {@link kTYPE_RELATED related}.

docblock.long-description: This is the tag is the offset used to indicate an object unique identifier within an object reference.
This tag is the offset used to indicate a container within an object reference.
This tag is the offset used to indicate a database within an object reference.
This is the offset that should be used to store the object's class name, it will be used to {@link CMongoUnitObject::NewObject() instantiate} objects when loading them from their containers.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a creation time-stamp.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a last modification time-stamp.

This tag is an offset that should be used to represent the object's version, the version is a value that should change each time the object is saved: it can be used to check whether an object was modified since the last time it was read.

By default it is an integer incremented each time the object is saved.

This tag is used as the default offset for indicating an attribute's data type, in general it is used in a structure in conjunction with the {@link kTAG_DATA data} offset to indicate the data type of the item.
This tag is used to describe a pattern, in general this may be applied to terms that are of the {@link kTYPE_STRING string} type which are restricted by a pattern.

This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a kind attribute. A kind is similar to the {@link kTAG_TYPE kTAG_TYPE} attribute, except that in the latter case it qualifies specifically the {@link kTAG_DATA kTAG_DATA} elements, in this case it discriminates the elements of a list.

This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a domain attribute. A domain represents what kind of object the current object represents, it should indicate the nature of the instance it represents.

This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a category attribute. A category represents an area to which the current instance belongs to, it should indicate the main quality of the instance in regards to other instances.

This tag is used as the default offset for indicating the cardinality of a data attribute, it can take the following values:

  • {@link kCARD_0_1 kCARD_0_1}: Zero or one, the data is either a scalar or it may not be present.
  • {@link kCARD_1 kCARD_1}: One, the data is a required scalar.
  • {@link kCARD_ANY kCARD_ANY}: Any, the data may not be present or it may have many elements; in general this indicates that the data element must be an array.

This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a unit attribute. A unit is a measurement unit such as centimeters, in general this offset will hold a reference to an object that defines the unit.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a source. A source indicates from where an object comes from, it is usually expressed as an URL.

This tag is used as the default offset for indicating an attribute's data or content, in general this tag is used in conjunction with the {@link kTAG_TYPE type} or {@link kTAG_KIND kind} offsets when storing lists of items.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating an attribute's code or acronym.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating an attribute containing an enumeration code or acronym.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a namespace term reference.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a graph node term.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a tag.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a graph node.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a graph edge node.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a subject term or node.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a predicate term or node.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating an object term or node.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a path.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a title.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating an attribute's name.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating an attribute's description.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating an attribute's definition.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating an attribute containing a list of examples.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating the language of an attribute, it should be the 2 character ISO 639 language code.
This tag is used as the namespace and default offset for entities.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating an attribute's status or state, it will generally be an array of tags defining the various states associated with the object.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a role or function, this is generally associated with the capabilities or permissions of users.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a list of annotations, in general it will contain a list of key/value pairs.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a dataset.

This is the tag that represents the list of references of an object, it is an array of object references in which each element may either be the reference itself or the following structure:

  • {@link kTAG_KIND kTAG_KIND}: Relation predicate, it can either be an object reference or a string.
  • {@link kTAG_DATA kTAG_DATA}: Relation object, it will be a reference to an object in which the following elements may appear:
    • {@link kTAG_REFERENCE_ID kTAG_REFERENCE_ID}: The unique identifier of the referenced object.
    • {@link kTAG_REFERENCE_CONTAINER kTAG_REFERENCE_CONTAINER}: The {@link CContainer container} name.
    • {@link kTAG_REFERENCE_DATABASE kTAG_REFERENCE_DATABASE}: The database name.
    • {@link kTAG_CLASS kTAG_CLASS}: The object class name.
This is the tag that represents a generic count.

This is the tag that represents the references count of an object, it is an integer representing the number of times the object was referenced. It is used in general to count the number of term data instances.
This tag represents a list of attribute tags, it is generally used to collect the list of tags used in an object.
This tag represents a list of data tags, it is generally used to collect the list of data tags that reference the current object.
This tag represents a graph edge node by using its related terms as a path in the form of a string containing the SUBJECT/PREDICATE/OBJECT path constituted by the term identifier elements.

This tag represents a graph edge node by using its related nodes and predicate term as a path in the form of a string containing the SUBJECT/PREDICATE/OBJECT path in which the subject and object elements are represented by the respective node identifiers, and the predicate element is represented by the edge term identifier.

This is the tag that represents the default entry related to the current one. There may be cases in which an object is interchangeable with many others, in enumerations, for instance: in this case we can use this tag to point to the default or used instance.

This is the tag that represents the preferred entry related to the current one. There may be cases in which an object may be obsolete, but still in use, this tag refers to the object that should be used in place of the current one. This tag expects the value of the {@link kTAG_LID native} identifier of the preferred object here.

This is the tag that represents the valid entry related to the current one. There may be cases in which it is not an option to delete objects, so we create a new one and the old one will point to the new one. This tag represents that property and it expects the value of the {@link kTAG_LID native} identifier of the new object here.
This tags provided elements as opposed to {@link kTAG_GENERATED generated} elements.
This tags generated elements as opposed to {@link kTAG_PROVIDED provided} elements.
This is the tag that represents the incoming direction, it can be used for tagging items that point to the current object.
This is the tag that represents the outgoing direction, it can be used for tagging items that the current object points to.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating the manager of the current object.
This is the tag that represents a password; the value is a string.
This is the tag that represents a mailing address, the value may either be a string or an array.
This is the tag that represents an e-mail, the value may either be a string or an array.
This is the tag that represents a telephone number, the value may either be a string or an array.
This is the tag that represents a telefax number, the value may either be a string or an array.
This is the tag that represents an URL, link or web address.
This is the tag that represents a list of acronyms.

This is the tag that represents the version, it should not be confused with the {@link kTAG_VERSION kTAG_VERSION} which is automatically managed in the class library: this offset represents the actual version.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a namespace name or acronym.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating an images list.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a file reference.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a list of files.
This tag is used as the default offset for indicating a list of columns.
This is the tag that represents a place or named location.
This is the tag that represents a care of address reference.
This is the tag that represents a place or named location.
This is the tag that represents a ZIP code.
This is the tag that represents a city name.
This is the tag that represents a province name or code.
This is the tag that represents an ISO3166 3 character country code.
This is the tag that represents the full data as a string.

This is the tag that defines the IS-A predicate.

This predicate is equivalent to a subclass, it can be used to relate a term to the default category to which it belongs within the current ontology.

This is the tag that defines the PART-OF predicate.

This predicate indicates that the subject is part of the object.

This is the tag that defines the COMPONENT-OF predicate.

This predicate indicates that the subject is a component of the object.

This is the tag that defines the SCALE-OF predicate.

This predicate is used to relate a term that can be used to annotate data with its method term or trait term.

This is the tag that defines the METHOD-OF predicate.

This predicate is used to relate a term that defines a measurement method to the trait term.

This is the tag that defines the ENUM-OF predicate.

This predicate is used to relate {@link kTAG_ENUM enumeration} terms, this edge type relates enumeration terms in a hierarchy.
This is the tag that defines a cardinality of zero or one.
This is the tag that defines a cardinality of exactly one.
This is the tag that defines a cardinality of any kind.
This is the tag that defines a taxon rank.
This is the tag that defines a taxon epithet.
This is the tag that defines a taxon authority.
This is the tag that defines a full taxon epithet.
A flag is the image of a flag or an icon symbol representing an object, the thumbnail flag is a small sized version of this image.
A flag is the image of a flag or an icon symbol representing an object, the medium flag is a medium sized version of this image.
A flag is the image of a flag or an icon symbol representing an object, the vector flag is a vector version of this image which can be resized at will.
This enumeration represents a disabled operator.
This enumeration represents equality.
This enumeration represents inequality.
This enumeration represents case and accent matching (for strings).
This enumeration represents case and accent non matching (for strings).
This enumeration represents prefix comparaison: starts with (for strings).
This enumeration represents prefix comparaison: starts with (for strings) with case and accent insensitive matching.
This enumeration represents content comparaison: contains (for strings).
This enumeration represents content comparaison: contains (for strings) with case and accent insensitive matching.
This enumeration represents suffix comparaison: ends with (for strings).
This enumeration represents suffix comparaison: ends with (for strings) with case and accent insensitive matching.
This enumeration represents a regular expression (for strings).
This enumeration represents less than.
This enumeration represents less than or equal.
This enumeration represents greater than.
This enumeration represents greater than or equal.
This enumeration represents a range including limits.
This enumeration represents a range excluding limits.
This enumeration represents empty or null.
This enumeration represents not empty or null.
This enumeration matches the value to a list of options.
This enumeration excludes values that match a list of options.
This enumeration matches a list of values to all elements of a list of options.
This enumeration is the negation of the match {@link kOPERATOR_ALL all} operator.
This enumeration qualifies expression terms.
This value represents the AND (A && B) operator.
This value represents the not AND (NOT(A && B)) operator.
This value represents the OR (A || B) operator.
This value represents the not OR (NOT(A || B)) operator.

This tag defines the current user instance.

Cardinality: one.

This tag defines the default Mongo instance.

Cardinality: one.

This tag defines the default Neo4j instance.

Cardinality: one.

This tag defines the current database instance.

Cardinality: one.

This tag defines the current container instance.

Cardinality: one.
This value defines the token that separates the object domain from other elements.
This value defines the token that separates the object class from other elements.
This value defines the token used to separate namespaces from codes.
This value defines the token used to indicate sub-offsets.
This value defines the token used to separate index elements.
This token is used to enclose namespaces or parent identification when merged with other identification sections, this value is used as a prefix.
This token is used to enclose namespaces or parent identification when merged with other identification sections, this value is used as a postfix.
This token should close all identification strings.
This tag represents the primitive string data type.

This value represents the primitive 32 bit signed integer data type.

This data type is serialised as foillows:

  • {@link kTAG_TYPE kTAG_TYPE}: Will contain this constant.
  • {@link kTAG_DATA kTAG_DATA}: Will contain the string representation of the integer.

This value represents the primitive 64 bit signed integer data type.

This data type is serialised as foillows:

  • {@link kTAG_TYPE kTAG_TYPE}: Will contain this constant.
  • {@link kTAG_DATA kTAG_DATA}: Will contain the string representation of the integer.
This value represents the primitive floating point data type.
This value represents the primitive boolean data type, it is assumed that it is provided as (y/n; Yes/No; 1/0; TRUE/FALSE) and will be converted to 1/0.
This value represents a binary string data type, it is generally expressed as an instance of the {@link CDataTypeBinary CDataTypeBinary} class.
This value represents a date represented as a YYYYMMDD string in which missing elements should be omitted. This means that if we don't know the day we can express that date as YYYYMM.
This value represents a time represented as a YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS string in which you may not have missing elements.
This tag defines a regular expression string type, it is generally expressed as an instance of the {@link CDataTypeRegex CDataTypeRegex} class.

This data type should be used as object references, it is generally expressed as a structure composed of the following elements:

  • {@link kTAG_REFERENCE_ID kTAG_REFERENCE_ID}: Object {@link kTAG_LID local} unique identifier. This value may be used as a scalar in cases in which the location of the object is univoque.
  • {@link kTAG_REFERENCE_CONTAINER kTAG_REFERENCE_CONTAINER}: Object container, reference to the container in which the object is stored. This component will be used in cases in which the container of the object is not univoque.
  • {@link kTAG_REFERENCE_DATABASE kTAG_REFERENCE_DATABASE}: Database container, reference to the database or container superclass in which the object is stored. This component will be used in cases in which the database of the object is not univoque.
This data type should be used for native time-stamps, it is generally expressed as an instance of the {@link CDataTypeStamp CDataTypeStamp} class.

This value represents the enumeration data type, it represents an enumeration element or container.

Enumerations represent a vocabulary from which one value must be chosen.

This value represents the enumerated set data type, it represents an enumerated set element or container.

Sets represent a vocabulary from which one or more value must be chosen.
This value represents the list data type, it represents an array of elements that may be scalars or other lists, this specific data type is a generalised tag for list structures.
This tag defines the number of seconds since January 1st, 1970.
This tag defines microseconds.
This tag defines a binary string.

This tag defines a binary string type (integer):

  • 1: Function.
  • 2: Byte array (use as default).
  • 3: UUID.
  • 5: MD5.
  • 128: Custom.
This value represents the primitive PHP data type, it is an PHP serialised object string.
This value represents the primitive JSON data type, it is an JSON encoded string.
This value represents the primitive XML data type, it is an XML encoded string.
This value represents the primitive HTML data type, it is an HTML encoded string.
This value represents the primitive comma separated data type, it is an CSV encoded string.
This value represents the SVG image data type, it is generally expressed in XML.
This value represents the PNG image data type, it is generally expressed in hexadecimal.
This value represents the primitive meta data type, it is a generalised metadata type.
This is the tag that represents an exact reference.
This is the tag that represents a broad reference.
This is the tag that represents a narrow reference.
This is the tag that represents a related reference.
This is the tag that represents a root term or node.
This is the tag that represents a namespace.
This is the tag that represents an attribute.
This is the tag that represents a term that rtepresents a structure.
This is the tag that represents a predicate.
This is the tag that represents a generic trait.
This is the tag that represents a generic method.
This is the tag that represents a measure term.
This is the tag that represents an annotation term.
This is the tag that represents an enumeration term.
This is the tag that represents a dictionary term.

This value represents the MongoId object data type, when serialised it will have the following structure:

  • {@link kTAG_TYPE kTAG_TYPE}: Will contain this constant.
  • {@link kTAG_DATA kTAG_DATA}: Will contain the HEX string ID.

This value represents the MongoCode object data type, when serialised it will have the following structure:

  • {@link kTAG_TYPE kTAG_TYPE}: Will contain this constant.
  • {@link kTAG_DATA kTAG_DATA}: Will contain the following structure:
    • code: The javascript code string.
    • scope: The list of key/value pairs.
